The game's story, which follows Peter as he balances his personal life with his superhero responsibilities, is engaging and well-paced, featuring a mix of familiar villains and new threats.

The gameplay is where Marvel's Spider-Man truly shines. Swinging through the city feels fluid and exhilarating, with a control scheme that's easy to pick up but offers plenty of depth for mastery. Combat is equally satisfying, with a variety of moves and gadgets at your disposal. The game's open-world design encourages exploration, and there are plenty of side activities and collectibles to keep you busy.

The remastered version on Steam looks and plays better than ever, with improved graphics and performance. The addition of all DLC content from the original release is a nice bonus, providing even more content to sink your teeth into.

Overall, Marvel's Spider-Man Remastered is a must-play for fans of the superhero genre. It captures the essence of what makes Spider-Man such an iconic character while delivering a polished and enjoyable gaming experience. Whether you're swinging through the city or taking down bad guys, you'll find plenty to love in this game.

I somehow forgot to review this game til now, but I think it deserves it.

Genuinely one of the best single player triple A titles you can play on Steam, this game offers a ton of content easily justifying its price tag. You can genuinely just swing around New York for hours and not get bored; they really nailed the feeling of just getting to *be* Spider-Man. 

It's supremely replayable; I first played it in 2018 on ps4 and my replay on steam felt just as good as the first time, this time also doing the DLC. Combat feels mostly fair and rewarding; there's a satisfying response to landing blows, and there aren't *too* many quicktime events on bosses, but they are still present. Going for 100% can feel a little tedious, especially on the DLC, but is not required at all.

Overall, solid 10/10 game. I rarely enjoy modern triple A games but I'd play this again any day.

Overall review: 9/10.

Spider-Man Remastered for PC on Steam is a breathtaking adventure. This remastered edition not only brings the beloved superhero to life with stunningly detailed graphics and fluid animations but also elevates the entire experience to new heights with PC-optimized performance.

From the moment you launch the game, you're greeted with vibrant visuals that perfectly capture the bustling energy of New York City. The attention to detail in the game's environment is nothing short of spectacular, making each swing through the city's skyscrapers feel exhilarating. The game's lighting effects, especially during different times of the day, beautifully highlight the dynamic world Insomniac Games has created.

The gameplay in Spider-Man Remastered is a masterclass in design. Swinging through the city feels intuitive and satisfying, thanks to the refined mechanics and responsive controls optimized for PC. Combat is equally impressive, offering a fluid mix of acrobatics, web-slinging, and gadgetry that allows for a variety of playstyles. The remastered edition further enhances this experience with improved frame rates and resolutions, ensuring that every punch, swing, and leap looks and feels better than ever.

Narratively, Spider-Man Remastered tells a compelling story that captures the essence of Peter Parker's dual life. The voice acting and motion capture work are top-notch, bringing depth and emotion to each character. The story missions and side quests are well-crafted, balancing superhero antics with the personal struggles of Peter Parker, making for a deeply engaging storyline.

The PC version of Spider-Man Remastered also benefits from additional features such as customizable graphics settings, ultrawide monitor support, and ray tracing, which elevate the visual fidelity to a whole new level. The game runs smoothly on a wide range of hardware, thanks to well-optimized software that caters to different gaming rigs.

In conclusion, Spider-Man Remastered for PC on Steam is an absolute must-play. It successfully captures the thrill of being everyone's favorite web-slinger while delivering a polished and immersive gaming experience. On the negative side, it does have a lot of 'filler' quests and missions to do that can be a bit too much (chasing birds, unlocking satellites, finding backpacks, etc). 

It's not just a game; it's a loving tribute to one of the most iconic superheroes of all time.

Finished the Main and DLCs in ~62 hours. Everyone should play through this one time and a big feature of the game is the accessibility options, allowing everyone to get a chance. I'm personally really bad at finishing single-player games, typically don't get beyond the first chapter in any game. But the engaging and epic story, fun gameplay cycle, the DLC that neatly continues the story, and the accessibility options, the cool spidey suits you can earn very easily, all had me coming back to finish this one. This is a taste of what games used to be and should be; there isn't a season pass needing a grind for 600000 Spidocoins to get a single glove, and I think most gamers can appreciate that.

[h1]I Have Nothing Left, Except Spiderman [/h1]
Game is really solid, boasting some of the best web swinging I've seen in these games. 
The story is highly engaging, even if they make Peter incredibly oblivious.
The games Arkham style combat is really engaging but a tad too easy. No fight even on the hardest difficulty NG+ brought much challenge to the games (especially the boss fights). Yet I'd be lying if getting 200+ combo isn't a hit of dopamine. 
However, the PC port is poorly optimised. Multiple times I had saves that would crash the game, alongside times the map tanked. Running it on lower settings helped but my PC can run most games on Ultra.
There's numerous bugs within fights, leading to enemies being stuck within objects or walls (sometimes making activities incompletable).
So overall I feel this game is really solid, a tad repetitive and not as brilliant as the hype made it out to be, but still brings brilliance to the table, being a fun 20+ hour run through (40+ if 100%).

With Great Power: A Review of Spider-Man Remastered

Introduction:
Spider-Man Remastered swings onto the scene with a polished sheen, offering both die-hard fans and newcomers alike a chance to experience the thrilling adventures of the web-slinger in stunning detail. Developed by Insomniac Games, this remastered edition of the beloved title sets out to elevate an already fantastic experience to new heights, promising improved visuals, enhanced performance, and additional features. But does this updated rendition of Spidey's escapades deliver on its promises? Let's dive into the web of excitement and find out.

Graphics and Performance:
From the moment you leap off the tallest building and swing through the bustling streets of New York City, it's evident that Spider-Man Remastered is a visual masterpiece. The updated graphics breathe new life into every corner of the concrete jungle, with enhanced textures, lighting effects, and character models that showcase the power of the PlayStation 5 hardware. Whether you're scaling skyscrapers or engaging in heart-pounding combat, the game maintains a smooth framerate and fluid animations, immersing players in a seamless experience that never falters.

Gameplay and Mechanics:
Spider-Man Remastered retains the addictive gameplay that made its predecessor a standout hit, offering a perfect blend of exhilarating traversal and satisfying combat. Swinging through the city feels more intuitive than ever, thanks to responsive controls and improved web-slinging mechanics that allow for effortless acrobatics and aerial maneuvers. Combat, too, has seen refinements, with tighter controls and enhanced enemy AI adding depth to each encounter. Whether you're dispatching foes with a flurry of punches or utilizing Spidey's vast array of gadgets, every fight feels dynamic and engaging.

Story and Characters:
At its core, Spider-Man Remastered is a tale of heroism, sacrifice, and redemption, and it's brought to life by a cast of memorable characters and a gripping narrative. Peter Parker's journey as both a superhero and a struggling young adult is as compelling as ever, with heartfelt moments of triumph and tragedy that tug at the heartstrings. The game's supporting cast, including familiar faces like Mary Jane Watson and Miles Morales, are given ample time to shine, each contributing to the rich tapestry of Spider-Man's world.

Drawbacks:
However, amidst its many strengths, Spider-Man Remastered is not without its flaws. One notable drawback is the lack of substantial new content or significant gameplay enhancements beyond the graphical overhaul. While the improved visuals are undeniably impressive, some players may have hoped for additional missions, challenges, or gameplay mechanics to justify the remaster's existence. Some players may find the challenges, Spider-Man Remastered's version of side quests, to be a bit repetitive. Furthermore, despite the enhancements, occasional technical hiccups such as texture pop-in and minor framerate drops can still occur, detracting from an otherwise seamless experience.

Conclusion:
Spider-Man Remastered is more than just a visual upgrade; it's a love letter to one of Marvel's most iconic heroes, painstakingly crafted with care and attention to detail. From its breathtaking graphics to its addictive gameplay and captivating story, this remastered edition stands as a shining example of what a superhero game can achieve when done right. Whether you're a longtime fan or a newcomer to the world of web-slinging, Spider-Man Remastered is an experience that demands to be played, offering countless hours of excitement, emotion, and above all, fun. With great power comes great responsibility, and Insomniac Games has once again proven themselves worthy of the mantle.

This is one of my favorite games of all time.
This is the definition of what video games should be, the stories it can tell, how it can move you, teach you, connect with you and inspire you.

First of all, the gameplay is great. The swinging feels amazing, it's really fun to just go from one point to another in the map. The combat is also great, it has enough depth to make it fun, while adding gadgets and other things that make it more interesting. The music is beautiful, and the graphics are superb.
Overall, the game is just really fun to play.

But the most important thing, is the story. This game has a story that includes growth, goodness and resilience. It has great dialogue, characterization and voice acting, but what truly matters is what the story is trying to say, what it is trying to tell you and show you. This is a story that makes you admire its characters, feel the emotions they are feeling, and learn from the experiences they face.
This is what videogames should strive to be, a medium to tell a story or share and experience that leaves an impact on the player.
One that inspires you, teaches you, connects with you and makes you feel something.

Spider-Man for the PlayStation 1 was the first console video game I ever played. Two decades later i'm playing it again, only this time - the definitive experience. 

Everything down to the NPC design is astonishing. The web swinging, the city, the sounds, mechanics, and narrative are masterfully crafted. This is an amalgamation of every good thing to ever come out of a webhead's game amplified x20, stripped of all the hiccups, while adding several new layers to the way you engage. Insomniac really gave new life to Spidey in the realm of gaming. 

The story is a character study or sorts. A journey of an already established hero at a crossroads that consists of epiphany and revelation. Serious with a few. Mentor to some. Friend to all. The dynamic between MJ and Pete was also a breath of fresh air. Through my little subjective lens, Mary Jane's character is best in her element when she's outside of the damsel in distress archetype. The antagonists, (especially Otto) were outstanding. Miles is the Cherry on top.

Exciting. Original. Heartfelt.

Fighting is seamless & extremely satisfying. Implementation of an Arkham style combat system was 110% the way to go. Even though it's very similar to the Arkhamverse's here - it still manages to establish it's own identity through the agile acrobatic move-sets and various combinations of web gadgets. Swinging with the quick zipping mechanic is such an engaging feature when it comes to combos.

Lastly, the environment and level design are breathtaking. Found myself at moments in time, atop random NYC high rises, just taking it all in. Buildings, weather, city life, (especially rooftops) are full of vitality. Did I mention the addictive swinging?

Not a huge spider-man fan but this was a fun game I would recommend as long as you don't pay full price. 

Pros:
1. Fun web swinging when it's working for you and not against you. 
2. OK combat. (see more below)
3. A story. Sort of... (see more below)
4. Not bad graphics. Skin and faces are pretty well done.

Meh:
1. Pedestrians/AI are passable. Once you play for a while you start noticing how shallow/dumb they actually are.
2. OK combat. Lets be real you really just hit square/X a bunch between hitting the R1 button where your web gadgets are. There's a selection of gadgets and suit powers and a few modifications you can do but once you find the combo that works the best you just kind of ignore the rest unless a challenge forces you to use them.
3. A story. Not so much of a story as a bunch of little short stories thrown together. The villains were kind of lame and I just didn't care for them or their story. Apparently the story will continue in Miles Morales but I didn't finish remastered in time to know If I wanted to play the sequel(s) to catch it on sale so I'm not going to buy it/them yet. 
4. No Avengers cameo's? Missed opportunity! 

Cons:
1. Very short game with not a whole lot of content. I'm usually the player that will explore the entire map before continuing to the main story area and I basically finished everything in 44 hours. Satisfied I suppose, but only because I got the game at 50% off. 
2. DLC 2 or 3 or 4 my PS4 controller (on PC) something in the game programming makes doing finishing moves and suit powers a 50/50 chance instead of working perfectly like they did the rest of the game. This is for any type of controller I read on the internet. It can make getting good scores in challenges nearly impossible but it's not going to break your game. It'll piss you off when you're trying to hit L3 + R3 surrounded by 20 enemies and it's just not F'ing working!!!! You'll get past it though and it's ONLY when you get into DLC 2/3/4. It works perfectly the rest of the game. 
3. PC crashes. The later into the game I got, the more often it seemed to crash. The type of crash where the game is running perfectly and without any warning at all the game just closes itself and an error report pops up. Again, annoying, but it only happened a grand total of maybe 10 times. Auto-save saves your ass most of the time and it only really stings if you're on wave 6/6 of a hideout that you've already failed at 4 times already. Again, annoying but not "i'm not buying this game" worthy. 

They could make an Iron-Man or a Dr. Strange stand-alone game off this game engine I think. Tweak a few things to make their powers/skills fit and it would probably sell. I'd probably buy them.

Spider-Man Remastered has not only swung its way into my heart but has redefined what it means to experience the life of everyone's favorite web-slinger. Insomniac Games has delivered a remaster that not only pays homage to the original masterpiece but elevates it to new heights with stunning visuals and enhanced gameplay.

The first thing that grabs your attention is the jaw-dropping visual overhaul. From the intricacies of Spider-Man's suit to the bustling streets of New York City, every detail is meticulously crafted. The ray tracing, improved textures, and enhanced lighting bring the iconic city to life like never before, creating a visual feast that's both nostalgic and breathtaking.

The fluidity of the web-swinging and acrobatics is where Spider-Man Remastered truly shines. The controls are responsive and intuitive, making navigation through the city a sheer joy. The addition of the haptic feedback on controllers adds an extra layer of immersion, making every swing and combat move feel more dynamic and engaging.

The revamped character models and animations contribute to a more cinematic experience, deepening the emotional connection to the story. The voice acting remains top-notch, capturing the essence of each character and immersing players in Spider-Man's world.

The inclusion of the three additional suits, each with its own unique abilities, is a welcome addition for both returning fans and newcomers. The attention to detail in the suit designs and the nod to Spidey's rich comic book history showcases the love and passion Insomniac Games has for the source material.

The overall performance and optimization of Spider-Man Remastered are commendable. The game runs smoothly, and load times are significantly reduced, ensuring a seamless and immersive experience that keeps you in the action.

In conclusion, Spider-Man Remastered is not just a remaster; it's a love letter to Spider-Man fans. Insomniac Games has taken an already outstanding title and polished it to perfection, making it a must-play for both fans of the original and newcomers eager to experience the web-slinging adventure in its most refined form. Grab your web-shooters and swing into action – this remaster is an absolute triumph! 🕷️🕸️🏙️🌟

As one of the most iconic superheroes of all time in marvel universe, Spider-Man has swung his way into the hearts of fans across generations. With the release of Spider-Man Remastered for PS4, PS5 and PC, Insomniac Studio brings the beloved adventure to a new platform, promising enhanced graphics, smoother gameplay and an immersive experience for players.

VIsually, the game takes full advantage of modern hardware, offerering stunning graphics with crisp textures, detailed character models and vibrant environments by applying the latest graphic technology. From the skycrappers to the bustling streets and every corner of each cities feels alive and immersive, inviting players to explore its intricacies, and one of the most significant improvement for the PC version is the crashing issues, sometimes plays smoothly and crashes continuously due to the hardware temperature and performance although my hardware has reach beyond the recommended game's specification.

But it's not just the visuals that received an upgrade; Spider-Man Remastered introduces a host of improvements and new features that make the gameplay experience even more enjoyable. The addition of haptic feedback on the DualSense controller adds a tactile dimension to swinging and combat, making each punch and web-slinging motion feel more impactful and responsive.

It wouldn't be a Spider-Man game without an engaging story, and Remastered delivers on this front as well. The narrative remains as compelling as ever, weaving together elements of action, humor, and heartfelt emotion that capture the essence of Spider-Man's journey. Whether you're battling classic villains like Doctor Octopus or unraveling the mysteries of Peter Parker's personal life, the story never fails to captivate.

One of the most significant additions to Spider-Man Remastered is the inclusion of all three DLC story chapters from the original game, seamlessly integrated into the main campaign. This provides even more content for players to sink their teeth into, further expanding upon the rich tapestry of Spider-Man's world. In addition to technical enhancements, Spider-Man Remastered on PC includes all the content from the original PlayStation release, including the base game and all three DLC story chapters. This means players can experience the full breadth of Spider-Man's adventures, from battling classic villains to delving into Peter Parker's personal struggles, all in one comprehensive package.

As I mentioned above, Spider-Man Remastered on PC is not without its drawbacks. Some players have reported encountering technical issues, including performance hiccups, crashes, and optimization issues on certain hardware configurations. While these issues may be addressed through future patches and updates, they can detract from the overall experience for some players.

Despite these minor drawbacks, Spider-Man Remastered on PC delivers an exhilarating and immersive superhero experience that fans of the genre won't want to miss. With its stunning visuals, smooth gameplay, and comprehensive content, it's a must-play for anyone looking to step into the shoes of the legendary web-slinger and swing through the streets of New York City like never before.

TLDR: I enjoy playing this game a lot, and I'm going to keep playing it for many hours, but the level of crashes on save load makes it a constant risk that I will lose all my progress. I couldn't recommend a game like that to a friend and have it on my conscience if they did lose their progress after hours of play.

The Good: The basic fighting is fast-paced and satisfying. It moves fast enough that you don't have a lot of time to think about what you're doing, which means you have to learn to internalise a strategy. As the fights get harder you're also unlocking new tools to help you handle things in new ways that you roll into your strategy and you have to get more flexible as the different sets of enemies and environments makes for a wide diversity of fights. The story is compelling as well, I haven't been brought to tears yet but the character relationships do regularly hit me in the feels.

The Bad: The boss fights are disappointing in that they all seem designed to be solved in a particular way. You have to check the boxes properly or you won't advance. The first boss fight for example there are a pair of huge turrets firing at you, once you realise it's signalling that you need to rip them out you need to time doing so between their bursts of fire. I thought I was clever, I went to one side to line them up so that one couldn't shoot me making it easy to time between the remaining turret's bursts. However then you can't rip it out from there, you need to stand in the middle to do that so that it can do the cinematic cut of the turret being thrown at the villain.

The Ugly: Crashes on save load, the worst time to crash because it means that you've essentially lost that save. I lost 2 hours the first time this happened when I died, I had to revert to my manual save slot which I started the night from. I started saving manually more often after that but then next time both the autosave and the manual slot were crashing. I poked around and reverted to the previous game version via the Steam beta menu and thankfully the save loaded fine. I got into this situation again and rolled forward to the current version and got around it, but I'm in constant fear that won't work. I now keep 2 alternating manual save slots, but I shouldn't need to do be so defensive of my saves.

[h1] One of the best open world games ever [/h1]

A long time ago, open world games started crop up more and more. The formula, arguably made popular by Assasssin's Creed, was translated into IP after IP. And all the games follow it to a T:
1. Create a fun gameplay loop
2. Have a big map 
3. Fill it with repeatable activities 
5. Try and find a balance between teedeum and enjoyment by skinnerboxing the [h1]shit[/h1] out of it.

All open world games follow this formula. Sure there might be some exceptions, but overall: from Far Cry to Shadow of Mordor, from Assassin's Creed to Horizon... they all do the. Same. Exact. Thing. 

So what makes Spider-man really enjoyable time? 

Well, first off the gameplay: this is where Spider-man shines. It's core gameplay loop is fantastic. It's ... very polished. Everything feels fun! Well... almost everything, but we'll get to that. 

Swinging feels fantastic. Going from one corner of the map to the other, is enjoyable in itself to the point that when fast travel is unlocked, you never actually want to use it. I've only found myself using it on my second play-through and only at the very end. There are several traversal mechanics that complement each other to actually give you different ways of getting from point A to point B, allowing the player to vary it up and never actually be bored with it. 

The combat, isn't anything to write home about: it's the free flow system. But it's polished. The gadgets are fun to use. The suit powers you unlock are diverse, creating different play-styles and the unlocks you get. The RPG tacked on Talent Tree also creates a feeling of progression. 

The issue  - and when I say Issue i mean it's what stops the game from being a masterpiece - is the contextualization of gameplay. They try and give in game reasons for the unlocking of gadgets, but it all feels forced. Talents are not even contextualized. This is Peter Parker well into his career, so he shouldn't still be "learning moves". Again, it's minor. Most games don't even bother with contextualizing gameplay. But great games do and do it well. Spider-man is just... kinda there. 

The collectables and activities on the map.... are a lot. OverWHELMINGLY so. The map opens up really quick, in fact from the first moment of the game you can go ANYWHERE. DON'T do what I did. When the "towers" become unlocked, I just went around the map finishing ALL the towers. Then a new side activity showed up. And then another. And another and another. Progress the story a bit. Then clean out the map. I ended up cleaning out the map in my first playthrough at least 5 times.

The reason being is that - I think - they found the perfect balance between Map size/ traversal enjoyment / fun activities. All activities are fun. And they never really outstay their welcome. I only started getting bored towards the finish of the second play-through. 

So to summarize, remove the story, and the game play is worth it just on it's on. You can ignore the  story and just have fun being Spider-man doing spider-man things in New York. 

There is one big issue: the one part of the gameplay that feels ... annoying. It's when you don't play as Spider-man. Playing as the side-non hero characters is... boring and tedious. Small stealth sections that, you realize don't require that much stealth. It's sort of padding, as they are kind of essential to the story, but i think they could have been removed. I think the point was to get to play as the side characters. To try and connect with them. Personally, no thank you. I came here to play Spider-man. 

However... if the first topic was gameplay, Story is the second. It's a great Spider-man story. Mind you, there are quite a few forced moments, in order to set up events, reveals. In fact, if the story has any real weakness, i'd say it has to be it's predictability. Realistically every single plot point you see coming, being telegraphed a mile away. This isn't necessarily a bad thing, more of a preference thing. There are no surprises. But what is given, is solid. It's a solid story, with great characterization, great performances and - despite predictable - great payoffs. No spoilers but Yuri Lowenthal's performance, especially in it's emotional climax, is the best performance an acted Spider-man has received in any medium. 

So, as a conclusion
It's a great game. Even at full price. You see it discounted at more than 25%, it's a steal! I Don't platinum games, because I can't be bothered. I was bothered with this. I played the entire thing, twice, on the hardest difficulty, just because it was fun to do. 

It's not a masterpiece, i reserve that for a special class of games, games that manage to create a synergy between, story and gameplay that is rarely reached. But it's really close. It's 70+ hours of fun.

Edit: The sequel is garbage. Don't bother. And i mean both Miles Morals and 2.

I gotta say, this rekindles my love for the superhero, starting with the good, the story is original, interesting and while cliched its never boring. The graphics, the swinging mechanics, all ported quite good for a PS port and I dont completely regret buying it for full price. 

But now the bad, the performance is slopy, it started out fine but at certain point it just dropped FPS like a video buffering on bus wifi, especially during hard fights this was noticable and annoying. Another kind of bad thing, although I can fogive it since its industry standard is rather boring bossfights, every boss has a tactic and spidey has a set of moves during cutscenes, which you just switch between, bit of swinging, some webshooting and same three moves and then back to swinging. Once its noticable it becomes boring as its just waiting to do enough to move on. 

Anyway I would still recomend this game, although as always, get it on sale, that way you get most time for your buck.

The game is fantastic.  My only 2 complaints are:

1. The stealth game play needs some work.
     - like being able to get off a perched ledge without jumping super high/swinging to another 
       grab point
     - or climb to the top of a building and be able to stop yourself on the ledge and not jump 30 
       feet in the air.  
     - Or even getting off a buildings ledge to land on the roof - you have to jump everywhere
     - and lastly, the stealth button indicators were very spotty for me

These are very minuscule, but also was very frustrating when forced to do missions in stealth

2. If I click 'Retry' after a challenge, my game almost always crashes.  If not the first time the definitely the 2nd.  I tried changing all the settings I could, lowered graphics, turn off DLSS, turn off all the extra stuff and it still continues to happen and it most certainly is not hardware.  This isn't my first rodeo troubleshooting crashing issues, but this happens every..single.. time.

With that being said, neither of these things should prevent others from playing, everything else is.. well, amazing.

Like a lot of games with cloud backup, it crashes periodically. It's a really fun game if you want some casual play (the hard settings really aren't hard). The web swinging alone is worth getting if you're into high mobility grappling hook mechanics. Plus, it reminds me of the Spider-Man YA novels I used to read.

It was beautiful. That I will admit. The cutscenes were top-notch, but I can watch a movie any time.

First off, too many concessions for console play.
the controls on every level were more wet and mushy than a 3 day old diaper. 'combat actions' relied on introducing new keys for every action rather than a logical set of simple controls.
The physics were absolute crap. 5 minutes of web-swinging in the city and you knew all about it. No controlled anchors, constant scripted movement in battle scenes, as well as scripted twitch combat. No anchoring whatsoever, even web-swinging felt like playing a hover game with minor 'webswinging' tweaks.

The movement engine was so damned console I felt like I was trying to play a mario game that demanded two dozen extra fingers. Basically, the story and graphics were great, but the gameplay was absolutely awful, like most console ports.

[h1] Marvel’s Spider-Man Remastered [/h1] 

[code] I would like to start by saying that I am a Marvel and Spider-Man fan, so this is not an objective review, rather a recommendation and my point of view. [/code] 
[b] I finished the game for the second time on the hardest difficulty (+ 1 completed on ps4) and I have to say the remastered version really brought the game to perfection  [/b] 

[u] everything from the swinging mechanic to the combat system fits perfectly [/u]

[i] the story is very well done so I really enjoy it,  the side characters seem very characteristic 
which I greatly appreciated because we see them for several times with a different faces and voices  [/i] 
[u] the game is set in its own game universe. [/u]
[i] the city feels believable and is full of side quests and activities. (some activities may seem repetitive) [/i]
completing the achievement is not difficult and its enjoyable 
 in terms of sound, the game is also very good, the music is <3 
the game is controlled very well especially with the dualsense controller, adaptive vibration and haptic response is perfect. [/hr]
 with my ryzen 3600 and rtx 2060 i played the game stably at 60fps on high settings with raytracing.

[u] mods can bring you many more hours of fun, from the suit to the fighting and swinging animations, fans there making perfect works, I've tried a lot of them myself. [/u]

[b]  in the end I would like to say that for me this spider man game is perfect, there is nothing to complain about except for the minor repetitiveness of secondary activities and the slightly stupid intelligence of the enemy, especially during silent killing. [/b] 

[b] thanks for the great work insomniac <3 , see you at Spider-man Miles Morales. [/b]

I had this rated as 6.9/6.9 but upon more playtime it's more like a 3.5/6.9.
My reason being: once you encounter SABLE tech, fights become all about spamming gadgets and hiding. You are not going to be able to dodge every attack because the movement is not fluid. The dudes with jetpacks and rocket launchers will shoot at you right when you get stunned or attacked by another enemy killing you instantly. It's so much more fun to fight the regular enemies rather than dodging or using a gadget in between every punch. I liked the beginning of the game a lot, but towards the end they have enemies that are not enjoyable to fight due to the movement being very wonky when in combat. Still a fun game with a good amount of playtime before it does get boring. I've never been too into comics and all that but Spider-Man has been my favorite superhero since I was a kid and this fondly reminds me of the one I used to play on GameCube.

After maxing the game with all trophies (excluding the NG+) I must say that I recommend this game mostly for casual gaming.

Don't get me wrong, the game is beautiful and fun, it has many mechanics.

But sadly it gets very repetitive when start to grind all the trophies, the crimes are being almost the same, enemies are just differently skinned models with the same behaviours (I mean the factions), there is nothing unique.

Game mostly gets harder by upping the enemies health or giving them more options that they block your attacks.

The story is really cool and I am looking forward to playing the next game of the series, but due to being so tired by repetitive tasks I am not sure I will be maxing it too.

The first run with maxing everything took me 40 hours, you can do it with maybe 2-3 hours less, since I was admiring the New York ;)

One of the better Playstation ports that they have done. Was so much fun to play, with a great story and compelling characters. 100% is very much a drag, especially if you want to get all the benchmarks although not required for 100%. Overall a great play

Plot 0 point
Well actually it's just another MARVEL game, where you must save the city. It's logical (most of times), understandable. But entire game you rescue someone, and beating "bad" guys

Characters +1 point
Peter is so Peter. Well, actually I really enjoy his unbreakable will to help someone, to see good in people, trying to reach on villans. I've red plenty comics book of SM, and in this game, we didnt see any difference of typical comix.
But if we talk about villians. Well that is what developing character is look like (except how fast this happening). And Black Cat is cute.

Gameplay +1 point
Fighting system is pretty easy and intuitive. Gadgets, combos, and most of it, flying is pretty easy and nice

Elaboration of the world +1
You have plenty of side missons. Game dont even make it difficult and just plants it in a map. And some these collects might make you laugh or sad, and even more unfold you Parker's previous life.

Graphics +1 point
Have no doubt. View of the city is wonderful

Stylistics +1 point
Armors on villians on the end of the game look really cool. And so much costumes of sm can make you individual interes. I actually have a question to Parker, why he carries so many of them all the time...

Music +1 point
Especially fight music and main. You really believe this IS SPIDER MAN notes

Optimization 0 point
Well actually the game have more bugs than you wish. Some of them not so scary. Yet some of them can make you restart the game even from previous savefile.

Modes, side quests +1 point
DLC's is quite interesting. Especially side quest with paintings. I have really enjoyed.

Personal influence +1 points
The plot and a nature of Parker might help you relax and believe you can make it through any hard punch your life makes.

This game is a tough one for me to review. I loved the combat and feel of being Spiderman, it really makes you feel like Spiderman, and that isn't easy to do. Web-slinging across New York never gets old (though I do recommend mods), and the way you can visit and climb anywhere and everywhere is certainly fun. The characters are fun, if not one-dimensional. This game has a lot of love put in, and you can feel the developers took care to honor the character and its world.

However, the mission design, compared to the rest of the game is outdated. Side quests consist of you going to somewhere and beating enemies there, or going somewhere and catching stuff there. Boring collectibles, repetitive side missions, mind-numbing challenges, all contribute to the game becoming stale for me as I played longer. This game isn't exactly cheap, and with that in mind, I couldn't wait to get the game over with, and that is really a shame.

Overall, it's a pretty good game, brought down by some bad sections and design.

I thought that the game was amazing and I had a blast playing the story mode for the base game. I would say that it was one of the best games that I have ever played, for sure.


The Good
The story was really good. I didn’t expect it to be that good but it was.

Miles is my favourite character in this game.

The graphics were really good. I never truly played a game at 4k until now and it was quite an amazing experience.

The gameplay was really good. 

The accessibility options are really good. Being able to skip the puzzles was so great. And being able to hold to tap was good too. Tapping would hurt my carpel tunnel hands.

The game was easy.

There a ton of unlockable that you can get.

There was one part in the game where you had to face rhino and scorpion, and the way that the scene was composed was so awesome. It was a fight in the rain on some dock, and a red spiderman is in the foreground, a grey rhino is to the right, and to the very back left is a green scorpion. It made me think of how much work that went into the game to have the scorpion crouching on some container looking like and actual scorpion. It was cool to see.

You can save whenever you want.

The games save folder keeps backup save files.

The game didn’t take long to beat which is a breath of fresh air for me. Many AAA games take so long to beat and they are almost always never worth your time. Also, I occasionally lost track of time while playing this game, which meant that I was immersed in the game and was having a lot of fun progressing the story.


The Bad
If you save during a mission and then quit the game to go do life stuff, your save file will get corrupted and crash when you load it up. Manually, saving after and before missions is mandatory. And backing up your saves should be mandatory too.

If you don’t do a good job on a challenge and want to retry, the game will crash. If you try to continue from the main menu, your game will crash. You will need to use your last manual save to continue to play the game. Only way to get out of the challenge is to just not retry and then go back to station and do it again.

Sometimes fast travelling will crash the game and you cannot continue your save from the main menu. You will need to use your last manual save to continue the game. I believe this happens when you try to fast travel during a mission.

The game is kind of buggy. Sometimes weird stuff will happen. Like sometimes you’ll have to reload your last checkpoint because the game softlocks itself and won’t let you complete a kill all the enemies for the story mode even though you did.

I thought that the DLC was bad. It felt like a Saturday morning cartoon of your favourite show but it wasn’t a regular 3 part episode, it was just a 3 part filler episode. In my opinion, this DLC sucked. I didn’t like the white haired woman who I thought left for good, and I didn’t like the predictable black cat story. And I didn’t like the last boss battle. It was tedious and a chore to beat that boss.


Conclusion
I think the base game for this spiderman game was amazing and I really enjoyed it. I’m not sure if I’ll ever play this game again but I have a good memory of it.

Amazing game (pun intended) with fantastic voice-work, great graphics and wonderfully realized open world version of NYC.  Insomniac has nailed what makes Spidey so cool and has translated that into incredibly fun gameplay mechanics.  Story-wise it's nothing that special but it is mostly reverent in its treatment of the various Spider-man characters.  The only real nitpick I could make are the lame Mary Jane Watson and Miles Morales stealth missions, which not only feel out of place in some ways but which also (unfortunately) break up the fun Spider-man action to slow things down by forcing you to play as boring characters.  

People are playing this game to be Spider-man, not Mary Jane Watson, Insomniac.  SMH

Anyway, that is really the only complaint I can come up with, honestly.  The Spidey traversal and web-slinging is fantastically done and just feels perfect.  A few times combat got a bit over-the-top in its difficulty levels and what they expected from the player but thanks to the smart addition of an adjustable difficulty level, that wasn't a major frustration, otherwise I'd have knocked off some points from my scoring.
(If only the over-rated Souls games would learn from this idea.)

Great game, well worth your money and time. Overall Review:
🏆 Rating: 9/10

Spider-Man Remastered swings onto PC with a breathtaking visual upgrade, bringing Insomniac Games' beloved superhero adventure to new heights. The enhanced graphics breathe new life into the vibrant streets of New York City. From the glistening skyscrapers to the minutest details in Spidey's suit, the level of detail is nothing short of impressive. The ray tracing, improved textures, and lighting effects create a cinematic experience that showcases the true potential of next-gen gaming.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3134765627
Game Elements:
🕹️ Graphics: ★★★★★
🗺️ Story: ★★★★☆
🎮 Gameplay: ★★★★☆
🗿 Difficulty: ★★★☆☆

Beyond its stunning visuals, Spider-Man Remastered excels in delivering an immersive and fluid gameplay experience. The intuitive controls and seamless web-swinging mechanics make traversing the city a joy, capturing the essence of being the friendly neighborhood Spider-Man. The combat system, a perfect blend of acrobatics and powerful attacks, remains as exhilarating as ever. With the addition of haptic feedback and adaptive triggers on the DualSense controller, players feel every swing, punch, and web-shoot with a level of responsiveness that deepens the connection to the iconic superhero.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3136216246
Spider-Man Remastered not only pays homage to the beloved comic book character but also elevates the overall superhero gaming experience. The well-crafted narrative, enhanced by top-notch voice acting by Yuri Lowenthal (robbed at the game awards this year), propels players into the dual life of Peter Parker and Spider-Man. The inclusion of all downloadable content add extra layers to an already rich experience. For fans and newcomers alike, Spider-Man Remastered is a must-play title that seamlessly combines stunning visuals, engaging gameplay, and an authentic portrayal of one of Marvel's most iconic characters.

I just finished the main story and all I can say is "Wow"!

The story is an emotional rollercoaster that any Spider-Man, or really anyone can enjoy.  You become emotionally invested in the characters and you start to feel like Peter Parker as the story unfolds.

Webslinging through the city is amazing when you first experience it, and it never gets old.

Graphically that game is just gorgeous.  I played on my Steam Deck and I have zero complaints.  I didn't experience any issues and everything moved fluidly.

I cannot recommend this game enough.  I really hope Spider-Man 2 comes out on Steam as well, but till then do not pass this game up!

It's short, it's full of focused story missions and collectables, and it's AWESOME.
SO many things about this game look like an ubisoft towers and collectibles adventure game, but it's so much more.

The writing is fun, the story is focused and snappy and has very little dead air, and most importantly, the gameplay is super fun. You feel like spiderman. I think there's a fast travel system in this game, but I can honestly say I never used it. Travelling between objectives is great. Swinging from a building mid mission to tie up some muggers is great. Dodging rockets and throwing turrets is great.

It's hardly Amazing (or Spectacular). I was very much looking forward to this, but now I really wouldn't recommend touching it without a pretty big discount and a lot of time you want to kill. Not exactly bad, but generally just fairly dull and repetitive.

The best thing about it is often the traversal. Swinging through the city can be very fun and engaging, but achieving a whole lot of precision with it can be a challenge. The barrier to entry is holding down a button, but getting exactly where you want to get can be a challenge.

Combat is probably the most annoying thing overall. It's alright in small doses, but the game really likes sticking to a formula of sending six waves of repetitive goons at you to pad the time. The mechanics are also not nearly as polished as we've grown to expect from Arkham games. You run into undodgeable attacks, zero warnings and in some missions, enemies that are so broken that they manage to hug you into a lock from as far as 3 to 4 meters away. I recall actually really enjoying long fights in Batman games because the counters were well times, you didn't feel screwed by chance and adding up those combo would build up momentum and power, that you could also unleash with a power attack. In this game you just hope something won't screw you up on wave 6. Especially not an enemy stuck in a wall and impossible to kill.

The game design suffers from being very specific in how it wants things done and doesn't trust the player to work it out by themselves. There's a lot of handholding and tutorial prompts don't wait a microsecond before telling you which button to press. Look for a vent. Press this. Shoot a web. Jump to the ceiling. Look for another vent. Boss fights suffer from this a lot. You will wait for special attack, you will dodge left, you'll shoot to close in and punch repeatedly. Now do this five more times because we're out of ideas. You get gadgets and no room to figure out how to use them in creative ways.

Writing is hit and miss. There's good acting in there, but it's recycling the usual suspects and you're rarely out of your comfort zone. Plenty of comic book logic and Deus Ex Machina. At least we were mostly spared another Uncle Ben.

The game is open world, but doesn't appear to know what to do about it. There's a single thread main story and it unlocks additional stuff to do. Burglary events, landmarks to visit, challenges. Very basic stuff, but if you happen to be someone who likes to get secondary content out of the way before pushing the story, the game will actively punish you with "Now to kill some time". It won't give you the next story mission and will expect you to go do something else, that at this point would be sitting on your ass for five minutes. There's the Jamerson radio host that periodically broadcasts rather amusing rants, but at least half of these were interrupted by random stuff happening around. I think you can replay them from the menu, but that's just frustrating.

Port wise, it runs great on a high end machine, but the crashes are real. Think I must've had one every 3 to 4 hours. There's also quite a few scripting problems, like enemies stuck in walls, character races where the opponent wouldn't move half the time, car chases that happened without the car actually driving. Sometimes the game wants you to take a picture, but the button to draw the camera won't work. Sometimes you get where you need to be, but nothing happens and you feel like an idiot, when it's just game script that failed to trigger the next bit. Exiting to main menu and reloading is something you get used to.

This game has become my present ADHD hyperfixation. Quite thorough accessibility options combined with a now pretty thriving mod scene that allows you to add costumes, change animations, voice files, or music, swap the lighting for a more comic-booky tone, etc., means this has become a game that truly lets you play YOUR Spider-man YOUR way.

Some important stuff up first: this game is a RAM hog on Windows, and a battery hog on Steam Deck, but otherwise runs very well on both. Also, the Steam Deck is going to get VERY warm while playing. I recommend playing while plugged in, and ideally not in bed where it's surprisingly easy to get blasted in the face by the utter SIROCCO of a wind streaming out of the Deck's air vent.

I shall not be following my own advice because, well, "do as I say, not as I do."

Now the meat of the review. 

This is the Spider-man that Stan Lee and Steve Ditko meant to write, with characterizations for all the major characters that treat them as human beings in all their messed up glory. It's nice seeing Norman Osborn in particular FINALLY receive a much more multifaceted portrayal here. And that's just one example. This game's take on Peter Parker, Aunt May, and MJ stand among the all-time bests, and I'm saying that as someone who very much does not typically like Mary Jane Watson much at all. This main cast of characters is a celebration of Spidey's history, past and present, and no main character feels in any way reduced or simplified -- each one takes inspiration from all of their past portrayals, but Insomniac still puts their own spin on each one.

So, let's now get the bad out of the way, I guess. I say "major" characters because bosses like Electro, Vulture, Scorpion, and Rhino all get very little personality at all, and amount to nothing more than speed bumps the player faces on their way to more interesting and emotionally invested confrontations. Then there's Hammerhead, the villain of the City That Never Sleeps DLC campaign who is... a johnny-one-note mafioso who believes in strength through violence for violence's sake and that's really all there is to his character. After getting incredibly nuanced main villains in the vanilla campaign like Doc Ock and Mr. Negative, playing CTNS after it all just felt like an endless series of disappointments as a result, especially given the extra highlighting that Screwball gets -- and if ever there was something in this game that would get me to NOT recommend it, it would be Screwball. 

Fortunately Screwball's mission in the vanilla campaign is, if not the shortest, mercifully straightforward, and the vast majority of her (significantly more numerous) DLC missions are all largely optional content. If only she was, you know, totally absent. She seems to have been written by someone who has HEARD of Twitch streamers but isn't too sure what they actually are, but has decided they hate them, and wants YOU to hate them just as much. And after the Calypso Twins from Borderlands 3 similarly landing that dynamic with all the skill and execution of a wet fart, I was hoping to never again see the "Evil Twitch Streamer" villain archetype again, but alas, here she is, arrived one more time to vex me further. 

There's also the much reviled MJ and Mile Morales stealth missions, which are less "stealth" and more "timing and positioning" puzzles, but tbh, they aren't THAT bad, they are relatively easy, and they mostly go pretty quickly, Rhino's "chase of goose" (that he hates) notwithstanding. The worst thing about them is they take you out of your rhythm as Spider-man and you spend most of their run WISHING you were still Spider-man.

Damn, I guess I probably have made this positive review sound downright negative for all the yapping I've been doing about parts I don't like. To err is human. 

Fortunately, that extended bit of griping aside, this is an immaculate Spider-man game. Traversal has never felt cleaner and more stylish, the combat is tight and VERY well executed, the story is one hell of an emotional roller coaster about past traumas and how if left unresolved and unaddressed they can become literal demons that derail our lives, and the biggest complaint I have left is that once you find your groove, it all goes SO MUCH FASTER than you want it to. Thank god for New Game Plus. Manhattan is a gorgeous playground that's beautifully rendered, even on low settings, even if it's a playground that no longer feels as expansive and huge as it did in the PS2 era when it was first used as a wide open sandbox. I do wish we got to see more of NYC than just its most famous bit, but what's here is lovingly crafted, gorgeous, and fun as hell to swing through and knock the teeth out of thugs, terrorists, fascist mercenaries, and supervillains in. 

Said teeth-knocking follows the Arkham formula of basic combos, dodges, and counters mixed with some gadgets and finishers, but that formula has never felt quite so POWERFUL as it does here. Combat will seldom feel stale or unwelcome, and it's been adapted quite well to a hero of Spider-man's agility. You will feel like you are in control of a comic book the whole time, and that's honestly what this whole game is about.

I give this four "not-quite-stealth missions" out of five.

After having played this game for 47 hrs beating the main campaign and dlc  I feel satisfied,  This has been my favourite spider-man experience but having played the arkham games the combat felt very similar, but its very good, especially spider-man's gadgets, lots of cool things you could do in combat with them by using 2 or 3 of them together. The story is good and features lots of cool moments featuring some of the classic villains and most of the characters are likeable and voice acting is great. The side missions are average, some of them good but most of them boring.  I found most of the boss fights a bit underwhelming, I feel that it could have been a lot better but there are some good boss fights too. I really enjoyed the increase in difficulty in the dlc also, the game just throws everything it has got at you, and it was much faster paced than the main story.

These are some of the negatives / Issues I faced

1. The Mary Jane missions and hacking puzzles felt like a speed breaker and felt super boring.
2. In screwball challenge missions the game had difficulty getting inputs from ps5 controller right, couldn't use the finishers   and occasionally there were issues with swinging also.
3. The game crashed occasionally, more times in the dlc part.
4. Average side missions. However the dlc side missions were less and better than the ones in the main campaign.
5. Occasional bugs where enemies you attack just disappear.

I would rate this game a 3.5/5. It is a bit overrated. I didn't like it as much as I thought I would but its definitely a good game.

As a fervent admirer of superhero escapades, Marvel’s Spider-Man Remastered swung into my gaming world with the promise of web-slinging thrills and graphical marvels. Here's my detailed web-tastic take on the game:

Web-Slinging & Visual Spectacle: 5/5
The sheer joy of swinging through the cityscape as Spider-Man is unparalleled. The fluidity of movement and attention to detail in the remastered visuals elevate the experience to new heights. Each swing feels like a choreographed dance, and the revamped graphics are a treat for the eyes. From the reflective surfaces of skyscrapers to the intricate design of Spidey's suit, the graphical fidelity brings New York City to life.

Combat Dynamics & Storytelling: 4/5
Combat sequences are a dazzling display of acrobatics and strategic prowess. The combo system and gadget utilization provide a satisfying depth to battles. The story, a compelling blend of superhero drama and personal struggles, keeps you invested in Peter Parker's journey. While some narrative beats feel familiar, the execution and voice acting elevate the overall storytelling experience.

Performance Swings High: 4/5
While the game demands a bit of graphical prowess, my gaming rig managed to keep up admirably. Some minor hiccups aside, the smooth web-swinging and breathtaking cityscapes make it a minor trade-off for the overall visual feast. The day-night cycle and weather effects further contribute to the dynamic nature of Spider-Man's world.

Conclusion
Marvel’s Spider-Man Remastered is not just a game; it's a superhero simulator. From the heart-pounding action to the jaw-dropping visuals, it successfully captures the essence of being Spider-Man. Swing into the revamped world of Peter Parker and relish in the superhero experience it flawlessly delivers.

This is a game based on an original property of one of the biggest brands of pop culture, the standards are high, Insomniac and Nixxes did a great job, it's a swinging success. 
There’s no reason to pass on this if you are into adventure games, as it stands, it’s a solid port, the definitive version of this hit action-adventure game.

The narrative is reinforced by a solid bit of world building, the streets of New York feel alive as pedestrians go about their business, the representation of day, night and in-between especially emphasized the verisimilitude of spidey’s neighborhood. 

The combat is proficient and is easily bouncing from opponent to opponent, a nice list of unlockable skills and gadgets bolsters an already decent move set. Even if you’re not a massive fan of superheroes, Spider-Man Remastered has a narrative with story beats that many will be able to enjoy and relate to, it’s the most realistic Spider-Man experience out of the comics.

However, it has it's flaws as everything, if you play it a while, you'll start to see its failures, in short, Spider-Man's open world design is a missed opportunity,  isn't necessarily a deal-breaker, but as an open world it is very oriented to the main mission, you can't interact with what it could have to offer, the high bar set in the main plot shines a harsher light on the rest of the game's activities, these don't have the same narrative energy as the main throughline, some of the side quests with the time passed might get tedious, but most of what is available entertains thanks to how great it feels to be Spider-Man. This is especially true when it comes to the more action-oriented segments and running around the city.

The worse segment of the game is when you'll be playing as MJ or Miles Morales. 
These sections aren’t engaging, to me it was the big downside of the entire game. 

Overall a recommended game, you won't regret buying if you are looking for fun, it's a good game, but not 'overwhelmingly' so.

Definitely a classic, but not worth $60! Spider-man remastered is a lot of fun, looks great, has a decently good story, and lots of side quests and collectibles to keep you busy. 

The core combat of the game is a ton of fun; mostly setting up ground combos to go into air combos, using some spider gadgets to web people up, as well as the option for stealth take downs. Once you get the hang of web swinging, it's a total blast to just swing everywhere instead of using the fast travel. Unfortunately that is kind of the extent of my praise for the game.

The main game is very short, I know I have roughly 24 hours at the time of writing this, but most of those hours is from side content and trying to stop every minor side crime in New York. If I only did the main story (not as a speed run attempt) I think I probably could have beaten the main game in like 4-6 hours. It's fine if a game has a lot of side content, just don't expect to see too much development in any of the characters besides Doc Oc's decent to madness.

One of the worst parts of the game is the forced stealth missions as MJ and Miles, they are total jokes for stealth as I usually sprinted right past the guards without them noticing. I understand that it was an attempt to breakup the usual web slinging and beat em up core of the game, but it was more annoying to do than entertaining or enjoyable. 

Perhaps its somehow my fault and I had the graphics set too high, but I ran what Ge force recommended as optimal settings, but I still had quite a lot of screen tearing and stuttering. The game would stutter so badly that the game would crash, usually if I played longer than an hour. I think I had the game crash about 6 times in 24 hours of game play. 

Other bugs I noticed were that sometimes looking through a glass window into a room, I would see through the building to a glitchy outdoors area. I think twice I had enemies somehow get stuck inside a wall alive, which you can't complete some side quests/bases until every enemy in the area is defeated, which is frustrating when it took 5-10 ish minutes to clear an area and then I have to redo it because of this clipping bug.

The game isn't a complete buggy mess though, but it does have more problems than a few other play station ports I've played recently. I do think the game was a ton of fun and would recommend just about anyone who is a fan of marvel or spider man to play it, just perhaps once the game is on sale because I don't like spending $60 on a game that crashes if I play for over an hour.

[h1] Overhyped, overrated, but still a good game [/h1]

To begin with, two things: first, I am not hardcore fan, I read few comics there and there when I was a kid, I played the PS1 game, and saw a couple of movies from early 2000's, so keep that in mind. Second, this is not the Spider-Man version of the Batman Arkham games. It doesn't even come close. The Arkham games are in a league of their own, and if you came here expecting something similar. Then you will be disappointed. However, Spider-Man is still a very good entry, with few caveats that break the pacing and the immersion. 
[h2] The Good [/h2]
[b] Gameplay [/b]: Swinging and jumping between buildings is ultra smooth and very fast as it should be. Fighting is responsive and fun with many gadgets and suit modifications to play with. 

[b] Sound[/b]: As you swing, the music intensifies and makes you really feel like you are the Spider-Man, out to get some baddies and save the city that never sleeps. It is really good and well done. Also the voice acting is top notch.

[b] Graphics [/b]: Looks and runs very smooth on 4k on my 6900XT, maintaining a stable 100+ fps with FSR enabled. Also for those who play on TV, HDR works very well.

[b] Misc things I liked [/b] There is tons of references that Marvel fans will definitely enjoy.

[h2] Mixed Feelings [/h2]

[b] Side Quests [/b]: They are fun and varied enough, but they greatly overstay their welcome. I managed to fully upgrade everything and get every suit and I still have A LOT of currency left to spend. I didn't bother to do any of the sidequests in the DLC. 

[b] The Story [/b]: It started good, but somewhere during the middle,I kinda stopped caring about what will happen next as it has gotten very predictable. But the walking parts weren't as bad as people make them out to be, I honestly find them relaxing and a good break from the action.

[b] Boss fights[/b]: Not bad, but could've been done in much much better way. 

[h2] BAD [/h2] 

[b] Mandatory Stealth Sections [/b]:No, I am not talking about being the bad ass Spider-Man webbing your enemies in style, I am talking about you being a weak normal human being. Forced to do stealth sections with no powers. Don't want to spoil anything, but these were horrible, unnecessary, and absolutely the worst part of the game. I wouldn't mind it if it happened once, and I mean only once. But no, it happens occasionally and you just have to force your way through it because otherwise you can't finish the game. 

[b] Self Talk [/b] I get it, I know that Spider-Man is quirky and has tongue in cheek humor and is lighthearted overall. But in this game, they extremely overdo it with the self talk. And I consider myself to have high tolerance for this, but the characters won't shut up "I have to do this, I need to do that, what will happen then? why is that?". In a way, it doesn't give you anytime to think about what has been said. Instead, the characters just talk and talk and talk non-stop during the game. So much that you just learn to tune it out. 

[spoiler][b] Miles Morales[/b]: I did feel for him during the story and he was authentic. But later on, specially during the DLC, he just won't shut up. I failed to care for him beyond the initial introduction point where what happened happened. But he is bordering on the level of Adoring Fan kind of annoying [/spoiler]

[spoiler][b] Screwball [/b]: Her sidequests were actually fun and challenging, but she also won't shut up. I am not sure but it seems they were trying to replicate The Joker with her. Bad attempt, and a very horrible character overall. I simply decided to skip her sections entirely. [/spoiler]

[b] Shoehorning the you know what [/b]: Can be easily fixed with mods. 

[h2] Conclusion [/h2] 
The game has incredible gameplay, and it is what saved it from a thumbs down. Swinging between buildings is really fun and they did a great job into making you feel like you are the Spider-Man. Make sure to play the game on Spectacular mode so that you can enjoy the fights and be forced to really use all your Spidey gadgets. On the other hand, don't expect much from the story or character development.
I will not get Miles Morales and I won't buy Spider-Man 2. This one was enough.

No pun intended, this was an amazing experience; Spider-Man is a well thought out game that delivers on every front, where I can honestly say the weakest part about the game was the graphics. The story was excellent, with a story inherent to Peter Parker that makes the player feel for Peter, his boss, his ex, the villains, and the innocent bystanders that you save along the way. The game play is Arkham Knight level fleshed out, with tight web and gadget mechanics, with a plethora of suits to fit anyone's tastes (Garfield's first suit, anyone? Just me?)

The weakest part of the game, and it's not even that bad, is the graphics and in world collisions. Every once in a while, I'd line up for a point launch or a maneuver through a water tower or fire escape, and the animation would feel slow, or clunky. Closeups to in world assets, such as cars, store signs, traffic cones, etc. are generally low poly, but it's nothing extreme, and doesn't take me out of the story.

With the main story and the dlc completed, it was the ultimate experience (that one was on purpose) for not just Spider-Man fans, but also people who enjoy a tight and well built game!
10/10 Game

Marvel's Spider-Man Remastered is a triumph for Insomniac games and a triumph for the superhero gaming genre. Marvel's Spider-Man Remastered sets it apart from most superhero games due to its unique game play and elements that aren't seen from a typical superhero game. Marvel's Spider-Man Remastered is a revolutionary game that incorporates all sorts of new game play. The use of Spider-Man's webs are integrated really well with the games combat which makes for some stunning game play. Through the use of webs, players have access to a very unique move set. The player can pull enemies towards them, yank enemies in or out of the air and many, many more. The air combat is also another fantastic addition which is a fun switch of combat. There is also a large selection of gadgets than can be used during combat. Each gadget is fun and unique in its own way. The upgrading system for these gadgets is also cool, allowing them to be improved even further. The gadgets correlate with each other extremely well which can display some awesome combinations. Then there's the traversal, swinging around New York City. This is certainly the best type of traversal in any game so far. It's so fun just swinging around the ginormous map of New York City while being able to see various iconic landmarks while traversing around. The swinging mechanics are just so smooth and it really makes the player feel like Spider-Man. There are also a few air tricks and other techniques that can be performed during swinging. All of this combined makes for some of the best game play out there. Also, the graphics are beautiful and New York City almost looks too real. The customisation is another noteworthy aspect of the game as there are forty suits that can be worn during the adventure. Each suit is unique in its own way and they all have some amazing little details on them. Some suits may look better than other but there isn't any bad suits apart from three or four. The fabrics on the suits look very authentic which are designed with lots of care. Each suit also comes with a unique ability. Each ability is great to use and they all offer fun game play. The campaign is definitely the best part of the game however. It is super long and has some awesome moments. The characters are fleshed out amazingly and have some great interactions with each other. Peter and Mary Jane's relationship particularly stand outs among others. The introduction to the main story is quite fun and it only gets better from there. The boss fights are done perfectly and each new one feels better than the last. The central villain for the first half of the story, Mr Negative is a very fleshed out villain with a very tragic backstory which makes for a compelling villain with sick powers. There are some parts in the story that mix up the game play a tiny bit with a few quick time events which are pretty cool. The DLC is also another great addition which focuses more on the women characters in Spider-Man. It introduces Black Cat which makes for some interesting dynamics between her and Spider-Man. The villain of the DLC, Hammerhead is another welcome addition. The Screwball challenges can also make players very frustrated. Her character in general is just quite terrible and annoying. The real highlight of the game is certainly the build up, relationship and clues with Peter Parker and Doctor Octavius. Throughout the game, Peter and Doctor Octavius's relationship grows stronger and stronger. It is a beautiful relationship. Then around the lab the players can notice several hints. Whether its seeing the plans for the super max prison named the raft, famous villains on the walls to even a new green suit in the lab. It is built up in the greatest way possible and seeing the doctor's transformation into the new antagonist of the game is so tragic but done so beautifully. The build up is certainly worth it and results in the best mission of the game where the sinister six is released and New York turns to turmoil. The cinematic's are stunning. The final act of the game is super fun with lots of boss fights and then there the grand finale. The Doctor Octopus fight. Peter makes probably the best suit in the game for the final boss. The whole game has built up to this final fight, and it is epic, climactic as well as the most emotional in the game. It pulls on your heart strings. Doc Ock makes for a worthy opponent and it is one of the best bosses in gaming today. The ending of this game will surely make you cry and then there is some large setting up which readies the player for the next game. However, there is one massive downside/fault this game has. That is the side missions. There are really only four good side missions that being the Taskmaster challenges which give a nice reward at the end, the Tombstone missions which include a fun boss, the Spider-Men side mission as well as the fun bases around the city. The rest are extremely terrible and drag on for way too long. None change up the game play, most of them are very repetitive. The crimes are the worst part as you need to do over 200 of mostly the same thing. It drags on too long. Though, the rest of the game makes up for this portion of the game. Marvel's Spider-Man Remastered has defined gaming in all the right ways. Not only is it one of the greatest superhero games, but it is also one of the best games ever. 10/10

This is a great game but a bad port.  It played beautifully for about 20 hours and then started crashing to the desktop.  I spent a bunch of time online and finally fixed this problem by adding a Registry key for TdrDelay of 10 and a TdrLevel of 3.  That fixed my crash problem.  Once again, the game was great for for a while.  

Unfortunately, after about 8 hours across multiple sessions of fun the game seems to have ground to a halt.  I'm now plagued with Incredible slow loading screen on startup, slow and laggy menu selection and blurry and stuttering camera pan once I get into the game.  My PC has been handling the game perfectly well graphically for the past 28 hours but all of a sudden it can't even load the main menu smoothly.  I'm finished with troubleshooting this game.

It's a good game but it's not worth the technical headaches to keep it running on my PC.  

Unfortunately, those errors won't start showing up until you're well past your return window on Steam.  

Do yourself a favour and give this one a miss.

A few hours of fun gameplay, wrapped in a lot of tedious repetition.
Controlling Spidey is a blast. Web-swinging is just as fun in hour 25 as it is in hour one. Combat is entertaining, but the lack of variety of enemies gets old fast.
I really struggle to recommend this game, though, due to how unnecessarily stretched-out it is. There's just so much padding - I feel like I fought the Demons for like a dozen hours before the real supervillains showed up. I can't tell you how little I care about Mister Negative. 
The real villains show up in the final act, but it was nearly too little, too late.
So much padding: the science puzzles, the MJ/Miles stealth sections that just feel like a K-Mart version of Metal Gear. I just want to play as Spider-Man. That's all.

I loved the web-swinging. Everything else was just window dressing.
