I wouldn't spend $60 on this, but $20-30 during a sale is definitely fair.

Just web swinging around the city is fun, even if it does behave in a way that makes absolutely no sense from a physics/momentum point of view. Still, I rarely wanted to fast travel since it was a good time to just manually get from A to B on my own and it was quite entertaining to try and photograph landmark buildings in mid-air without stopping just to see how many I could get in a row without landing in between.

Combat is ok. A bit clunky at times and some of the skills/gadgets I found to be of very limited use. There are enough awful QTEs in some story fights to make it feel like a 2008 game (I'm looking at you, The Force Unleashed) rather than a 2018 game, but at least there's an accessibility option to have the game auto-complete those for you so you don't have to even see them. Would have marked the game down otherwise, so nice spider sense dodge there from the devs.

Most (maybe 90-95%) of the side activities and side missions are decent fun despite the writing often including CSI-level inaccurate tech nonsense that made me roll my eyes, so I would keep cleaning these up whenever I unlocked them. You tend to unlock a new type of side content after every 1-2 main story missions so it keeps the map icons from being overwhelming and gives you a variety of things to do over time. Having a lot of the major side acivities take place at construction sites, in similar looking warehouses or on generic skyscraper rooftops is a bummer, but not too bad when many of the smallest side activites are instead happening at street level. A couple of relatively short missions where you control someone other than Spider-Man and mostly just traverse an area from A to B while dodging patrols were pretty mediocre, with the exception of one MJ mission that had a somewhat neat gameplay twist.

The map screen and the general UI I would consider serviceable but not great. It works, but it's kind of dumb how it only shows bonus objectives for a couple of seconds at the start of a fight and then again for a few seconds whenever you raise the completion counter on some objective. Same with the suit power so you almost never know how long it has left to recharge. Why hide useful info like that constantly by default, especially when the screen is far from being cluttered?

The whole MJ <-> Peter relationship felt like it was written with fairly insecure/immature teenagers in mind rather than experienced pros in their 20s. MJ taking insanely stupid personal risks just to somehow prove that she-can-do-it-alone, just because Peter is concerned about her being reckless while being a normal human in a city full of supercriminals and insane crime gangs felt very weird and possibly just a plot contrivance.
The Spider-Man <-> Captain Yuri working relationship felt way more like something one would actually find between adults and the whole Spider-Cop routine was exactly the kind of silly comedy I would expect from Spider-Man, so props to whoever wrote that and to Yuri's voice actress for an excellent performance.

The main story is generally somewhere in the ok<->good range for the most part (with some cringe writing at times) up until something like 75% completion or 20 hours (that's including all the side content up until that point). 
Sadly, after this point there is a most awkward character "plot twist" which feels like it instantly spoils most of the effort you put in up until this point, when really this was when the story should just have wrapped up. Because it's so obvious many hours earlier what is going to happen the very serious and tragic character arc they try to write throughout the game just falls completely flat and it just serves to sour the experience at this point. Had they kept this "twist" for the sequel so that you only had fond memories of a character from this game with you into the next game I think it could have worked on an emotional level, but now it just doesn't.

I really hate when videogame writers forcibly spoil your efforts in this way (Bravely Default did something similar) so I saved, quit and uninstalled. If you just stop playing before this bit, though, it's a really solid game.

The game is good.

However, it's value is nullified by:
- Random crashes (loading screens, during missions, when traversing the open world). Disabling DLSS3 or core integrity didn't help to resolve this
- Randomly occurring corruption of save files, one time verifying game files integrity helped, all the others it didn't and I lost progress since the last backup saves

These two things, unfortunately, make it very hard to properly enjoy the experience as instead of playing you're trying to anticipate when it'll crash/corrupt next time and preserve your progress by manually saving multiple times in a row after every more or less important action

I bought this game once switching to PC gaming. As an Xbox player, I can't believe we missed out on such a great game. I am writing this review after getting all achievements. It took me about 2 months of on and off playing to finish the first play-through of the story, and then I grinded the New Game+ and DLC content in about 2 weeks.
The game play is amazing. The swinging is so much fun and the way New York looks blew me away. The combat can definetly get a little repetitive, but I tried my best to keep it fresh by focusing on gadget combos in my second playthrough/dlc. The main story was an amazing Spiderman story with some very fun fights and missions throughout. There are a few boring MJ/Miles missions but they aren't very long and you can move through them pretty easily. If anyone is still considering purchasing this game, I would highly recommend it. I'm not usually a story game player but this game was one of the best games I have ever played. I really enjoyed myself and if you buy it, you probably will as well. 5/5 Stars, can't wait to play Miles Morales.

It is fun to swing around New York as Spider-man. The main story is great and I love how MJ's character is integrated into the game-play. Some side missions such as Harry's labs, taskmaster are also very engaging and I actually felt like they were worth doing. Many different suits to unlock and try on. Most suits have special abilities which are really nice. I appreciate that you can mix and match any suit with any ability. The combat gets repetitive very quickly but the boss fights in some ways make up for it. another things I noticed about the npcs is that if you take down an npc and another sees their body after they do not alert others about it which seems a odd. The web slinging is a little funny sometimes and trying to climb on buildings and walls does not work consistently.

Let's be real. You've heard of this game and you know it's good. Sure, it has its flaws, but with an excellent story, sandbox, and pacing, it engaged me from start to finish. Even though it has your typical open world fluff, the amount of it felt just right, and almost all of it is entirely optional. I rarely used the fast travel system because traversal just felt that good. For these points alone, as an open world game, it is a must-try in my book. I just wish combat was a little more difficult, because it is still too easy on spectacular difficulty with the abundance of gadget uses. Webbing up enemies with impact, trap and bomb webs were so overpowered that I never felt the need to use any of the other gadgets.

I was skeptical about getting this at first, since a lot of other super hero games have let me down in the past. However, the game went on sale and I couldn't resist giving it a try.

Playing as Spider-man genuinely feels like you are Spidey; very acrobatic and agile, you are also strong, but not invulnerable (quite squishy, actually). I like that layer of realism and challenge to it.

The story is not super great, but entertaining enough that I never got bored of it. The plot is predictable, but the writing of the dialogue can be interesting and sometimes funny.

There are a lot of customization options as well, so you can have some freedom on how you want to play.

My son bought it on Epic and it didnt work and I was joking saying "that is what you get for buying it on there and not steam" and we get the same error from Steam. I thought maybe his PC wasn't meeting the requirements and he did. I did some more research and there are a ton of videos with multiple methods to fix multiple issue that lead to crashing. Let me tell you. This game is fun as all heck. But the stealth missions are absolute dogwater. They break the pacing and are unfun slogs where you have to hope that the patterns are the exact same. I've had missions where the AI pathing just changes for no reason and I get caught because I didn't expect a drone to be somewhere. I really, really love this game when you're playing as Spider-Man, but when I'm playing as anyone else.. It's genuinely a slow, frustrating slog, that has made me want to quit about 4 times in the past 4 hours of gameplay. I want to play as the Spectacular Spider-Man! Not anyone else. I don't want to have to cower and hide when I could be kicking a bad guy in the butt with my Spider powers. The stealth sections as Peter are great, I love picking them off one by one as I get closer to my goals.. But if Spider-Man Miles Morales, and Spider-Man 2 are like this.. I genuinely don't think I want to play this franchise any further. 

I've had other issues, including the way health regeneration works. I play relatively conservatively, and I'm still getting my health zapped to zero in a matter of seconds on the "normal" difficulty. It's infuriating to be in a close quarters brawl, and then get zapped to one health, and not have the ability to regenerate any health whatsoever. Call it a "skill issue" but when the difficulty is set to specifically be a "casual experience to enjoy the story", and I'm getting my ass handed to me every few fights, even when I'm speccing into health regeneration and disarmament.. It is beyond infuriating, and makes me want to throw my controller down and call it.

I'm being really negative, but it's because I want this game to be fun. I've always been a huge Spider-Man fan, I've been one since I was a kid, and until I got to the stealth portions of the game, the difficulty was fine, I was enjoying myself thoroughly, but the random difficulty spikes in fights and the BS stealth sections have really put a damper on my enjoyment of this game. I've intentionally kept myself spoiler free (as much as one can for a 6 year old game, now.), and that includes gameplay mechanics, but if Miles Morales has similar issues.. I will probably refund it pretty quickly.

In all, for "Marvel's Spider-Man REMASTERED" I personally give it a Solid 9/10, omitting my major gripes. It really does make you feel like Spider-Man. But... The moment I'm not playing as Spider-Man.. It drops to a 6, 7/10 game.. I do recommend it, for a beat-em-up gamer, or a Spider-Man fan, but the stealth sections are absolutely not for me.

It's dope. 

Webspin and movement feels great. 

It's really strong in the beginning.. the game cant keep your attention in the lategame very well like in most open world games (def if you play the story and bigger sidequests in one part and you find yourself left with the typical missions you know from this type of games). But the movement and fighting (so many powers in the end, so many combinations and fighting styles possible) is really satisfying and enemies can bring up some heavy attacks so even with your skills and shit you can get into some real trouble, wich means I wasnt bothered that much about those symptoms in the end. Also so for the hardcore fanboys there are plenty of lore, skins and other geeky stuff to unlock.

The optics are outstanding and with some tweeking here and there I can almost run this fluently with my 3060 with "raytracing" on and bla so it's kinda optimized, although for streaming this game with nice looks that game was a killer for my system. Whatsoever the world felt really alive and even if you put your settings lower (i tried different settings to fix the stream and it didnt work somehow) like traffic and stuff the streets are still filled and theres happening something everywhere.

For every Spiderman fan this game is a mustbuy if you dont have other newer spider man games. My first one was for the gameboy and later the one on ps1 from activision.. wich was fun but not to compare with this here.. even later spiderman titles felt stiff and clunky in many ways.. this here is butter.

You dont have to be a spideykid to luv the game. Its one of many heroes with its game.. and I guess its compareable in lots of points to other titles.. still never felt so free in a city. Was surprised all the time what kind of creative possibilities had been possible by clever gamedesign. And although this game is mainly full of light and more friendly vibes the story is way darker then you would expect in impulse. 

I recommend checking the specs befor buying.. this game really lives from its optics too. and it's hungry af

it's basically Batman Arkham City, just with Spidey.

The story is.. ok. Nothing to write home about but not shabby either. Poor Otto. I was a bit surprised that by how much of the story is around Norman Osborn but the Green Goblin makes no appearance. I would have wished the other main enemies were a bit more fleshed out. You got Fisk, Mister Negative, Doctor Octopus, Vulture, Electro, Rhino and Scorpion as the main enemies (side appearances of Tombstone, Black Cat and Taskmaster) but only Doc Oc and Mr. Negative get any story, the others are just.. there. As someone with only limited spidey knowledge, a bit more info would have been nice. Hell at first and for a while it looks like Fisk was the main Baddy and besides "He's a mob boss" you get nothing.

As far as open world, it's.. not that great. Now, the city is modelled nicely and traversal s good. Swinging around feels great and I'm glad they don't let you swing where there are no buildings, tho I never bothered to check if the swing lines actually attach to anythhing.
But the normal open world "missions" are monotone as hell. Infiltrate that Fisk hideout. Ok, I carefully web all the enemies without being detected and.. oh, wave 2, a whole host of new enemies come out and all instantly know where I am? Cool.. So you defeat 6 waves. And every "hideout" is the same, as in, location looks different but it's just a several-wave combat area. And later the same again for other main enemies. And again. And again.
Oh there are crimes-in-progress. And it's like a random one of a pool of 5 or so types, most of which are kinda annoying and more time consuming than they should be. and it's 5 per district, of which there are 8 or so. And then there's a new enemy faction and yes, 5 per district again. And then there's a new enemy.. you get the drift.
If they were done in a few seconds, you know, like with collectibles in other open world games, or actually had something different to them I wouldn't have minded. Hell I didn't mind all the riddler trophies in the batman games. But it feels so monotonous here.

Most of the enemies where quite nice to fight, save for the whip guys, screw them.  Batman had the fighting down a bit better, but it works fine most of the time. It was just annoying that when you ziplined away instead of using the evade button, enemies with guns have a perfect aim still - despite both actions are spidey zipping away, just with different buttons. Especially annoying with the snipers, because one shot from them means half the health bar is gone.
I also had it once or twice that enemies just threw a punch and glided 2 meters to me, because I ran away instead of evading. I can't remember something like this happening in Batman.

All in all, the game was good, made fun to play, but let me realize once again how great the batman games were, because it doesn't quite reach that level.

The DLCs are included here and I'm glad they are, if I paid extra for them I'd be upset. They're not good. They introduce a few new enemies that without fail are all annoying to fight. They include a host of "new" same old bases, new same old street crimes and new Taskmaster challenges.. Except it's not taskmaster but screwball. A rather new (2008) spidey character that feels quintessentially millenial. She's maximally annoying - intendedly so, but that doesn't make her less annoying. And from what I can find from old threads when this game was a PS4 exclusive, everyone hated her, there were even articles written about how everyone hates her.. Yet she comes back in every DLC. DLC 2 was the worst tho. I love doing things the sneaky way, but her Tasks in DLC 2 with the stealth challenge introduced a "motion detector" search light, that's not always easy to see in scanning mode, can only be disabled for a few seconds and all of the challenges hae multiple intersecting motion detectors. Really took the fun out of it.
I was also a bit disappointed becuase from the image of them, I thought they'd let you play as other characters. DLC1 has the title "The Heist" and the image of Black Cat. Expectation: Oh you play as the Black Cat, plan a heist, stake the place out, then an extended infiltration mission to steal something, where you have to outsmart spidey at the end or something like that. Or maybe it's the story of the past, the heist that first let her meet spidey (dunno if there was such a heist tho). The Reality: Nope, more of the same, someone else is stealing some USB sticks hidden in pseudorandom places (which don't always make sense story-wise), no heist, no infiltration, just more of the same we already did.

I have yet to play the Squeal or Miles Morales, but this is not only one of the best spider man games I have ever played, but one of the best games I have ever played ever. So good I 100%'d all DLC and side missions.

3 Best Parts:
1. The Web slinging and movement in this game is GOD tier, I dont think I have ever felt anything more fun in a game in terms of travel. 
2. The voice acting in this game is very well done, all sound emotional and mean what they say. I have to admit I will be saying "CHASE OF GOOSE?! I HATE CHASE OF GOOSE!" in my sleep, best line.
3. The number of things added like Costumes, Gadgets,  Tokens, Side missions, Bad guys to fight, side missions (I know I said that, but there are ALOT), the way the city changes with weather, upgrades, ETC Is DISGUSTING in terms of amount to do, (I know my dumb ass did them all) Puts Banjo and Rare games to shame!

3 Worst Parts
1. The way it makes you WAIT and fucking wait and wait and wait between crimes in the city to get crime token and spamming the right thumb stick to find them is annoying. It felt way longer than it needed to be.
2. MJ is insanely annoying and toxic. I get it you are a "strong person who dont need no man", but she gets really annoying with her whining through half the game.
3 . The VERY END of the LAST Dlc boss ending was HORRIBLE! I wont spoil it , but dear god you can tell they were in a rush to finish it and wrote themselves into a corner and ran out of time

Again, all of these are more or less personal/ VERY MINOR issues like 9.9/10 game. Please for the love of god, play this game, if you like spider man play this game, if you like action, play this game, and if its on sale, I want you to stop reading this and play this game.....Why are you still reading this...I hate chase of goose.

This game is so much fun! I wasn't even a Spider Man fan before playing this, I just wanted a mindless game to play! I could go on and on why this game is a 9/10 or 9.5/10, but I must talk about some annoying bugs that really make me want to punch my monitor sometimes! 

1. At certain challenges or missions, I like to reload checkpoint, or retry the challenge if I didn't get all 3 medals... This can lead to the game crashing. I re-open the game, reload the save and it will crash again. Sometimes it won't crash and then I gotta hope I can do this challenge without failing, because 99% of the time if this bug is active, the game will just crash again. Really annoying.

2. Trying to do these challenges, like the combat ones can be really annoying because the finisher move DOESN'T WANT TO WORK!!! I'm spamming Y+B to get the finisher and Spidey is just cartwheeling around getting hit, losing my combo and points. Then I reload checkpoint and you guessed it... the game crashes again. 

I'd love to give this game a good review because it deserves it, and it already has enough, so I wanted to vent my frustrations and leave a review here about it. Apart from these bugs, the game is amazing and I definitely recommend buying it!

I suppose its not a secret that this is a great game. But the real trick for me is that I do not have to be 'bribed' by the game at all to want to play it and interact with its open world. Find a bunch of backpacks? That's awesome I get to swing around and be Spider-Man. Catch some Pigeons? That's awesome I get to swing around and be Spider-Man. Stop a Car Chase? That's awesome I get to swing around and be Spider-Man. 

I never feel like I'm being forced to do busy work to achieve some other end, like so many other open-world games, since I just love playing as Spider-Man so much. All the open world tropes and quests just give a purpose and direction, but its the game that is fun, the immersive feeling of being Spider-Man that is fun, not the mechanical joy of completing a to do list.

EDIT: After playing the DLC, it seems like a bunch of open world / video game tropes snuck in, escort quests, base defense, etc and especially the variety of enemies that took very specific tactics to take down. And while its at least "interesting" to say, "Well, I've got to take care of the snipers, then the rocket guys, all while avoiding shield charges, and trying to get hits in on the invincible fat men while I can..." it really cuts into the power fantasy of BEING Spider-Man. I preferred the gameplay of "how am I going to style on these guys" more than, "If I miss a dodge on a rocket, I'm probably boned." While I feel like I'm now much better at the game, you do have to raise your game to finish the DLC, it feels like I'm a better video game player, rather than a better Spider-Man. It seems like all the B-/C+ ideas that didn't get put into the main game found second life to pad out the extra content. Its still an excellent game though, and I'm happily going to play Spider-Man Miles Morales, which the DLC nicely bridges too.

[h1]Absolute blast! Through and through this game is emotionally packed with amazing story telling, beautiful graphics, seamless cutscene-gameplay transitions, and of course fun and fluid mobility and action![/h1] 

If you've ever been a fan of Spider-Man or Marvel, or even slightly curious, this game is a great place to jump in. If you're just a fan of fluid movement, fast paced action, and great story telling, this game is a great place to jump in. This is the first in the current 3-game-series following the story of Peter Parker as Spider-Man. [b]I highly recommend playing this before jumping into[/b] [u]Marvel's Spider-Man: Miles Morales[/u], and finally [u]Marvel's Spider-Man 2[/u][i](which is expected to hit PC in late 2024)[/i].

[h2] [u]Steam's Exclusive Offer adds additional content making this game especially worth every penny[b] ($59.99 usd)[/b] and a complete steal [i] on sale[/i][b] ($35.99 usd)[/b][/u]

[h1][b]Marvel’s Spider-Man Remastered[/b][/h1]

[b]Rating: 5/10 - Mediocre[/b]

Incredibly disappointing, that's what this game is. Sure, the movement is fun for the runtime of the game but that's about it. Combat is nothing special, most missions aren't that fun and the story is... boring and underdeveloped. They stuffed far too many villains into the game. The sinister six deserved way more than just a few fights. Non of them (except for the final boss) even get to stand in the spotlight. Then there is mister negative who is so boring and uninteresting that the game would have benefited from cutting him out and instead using the run time to more deeply explore the sinister six. On top of that is the standard, formulaic checklist side content. 

Just disappointing, but in the end the game is fun enough to be worth playing.

owned this game since it came out and STILL cant play it on my 10th gen I9 and 3080 mobile laptop. theres been a stated issue since launch about performance on laptops and still months later NOTHING. Id ask for a refund but ive waited too long thinking the patch for this would be quick. I never really give reviews but the support and performance of this title MONTHS after release is appalling. If you own a laptop gaming rig do NOT buy this game.

EDIT: After fixing then breaking then fixing again from nividia drivers it appears the game finally works as intended. Took long enough sheesh.

Very high quality title like all newer ports from PlayStation PC LLC.

Feels just like Spiderman, the character movement is so fluent and satisfying, 
It feels like an honest attempt at making a great spiderman game with no compromises and a lot of passion from the developers, effort and genuine love for the franchise.

Combat is nice and there's enough variety to almost keep the combat from getting old (it still gets boring by the end).
New Yorks' rendition is simply breathtaking, the missions can get repetitive which is a repeating trend in current triple A gaming and there's some 'stealth' missions where you use other characters (without powers) that are ok in the beginning but get really old, boring and annoying after the first half of the game.

The story is not a masterpiece by any means, the plot is what it is with some charaters that act odd for no reason and some events that feel forced to include more characters (which might be a welcome addition for the fans that want to see the most characters possible). The same with the action scenes, they're flashy and over the top but sometimes the actions ruin the immersion since they encompass odd decisions by the characters.

Overall I have to recommend this game, it's like you can't go wrong with any current PlayStation PC port.
Even if you don't particularly like spiderman as a franchise, this game is really worth picking as one of the current best action adventure games for PC.

I loved this. Becoming Spiderman and being able to, simply put, wallop anyone who did anything remotely villainous was a rush and a half. My only issue is that after I 100% a game file, I started a new game+ and found that the game started freezing at random points. At first I thought it was an issue on my part, but after almost a year of playing different, and in some cases larger, games with no issues, I've started thinking that it might be an issue with Spider-man itself. I have no issues with the Miles Morales port, just this one. 
If there are any other reviews that talk about this issue, please consider saving your money and getting the game on it's original console, or a different one. If you don't, just assume that it's a me issue and move on.

What you should take from this is that, if you really want an action-packed, narrative-heavy game, I personally wouldn't buy it, but if you like Spider-Man, swinging, and maybe a little plot and nothing else, you should grab it.

GREAT GAME

In the bustling cityscape of New York, "Marvel’s Spider-Man" offers a thrilling and immersive experience, weaving an exceptional narrative and delivering the quintessential Spider-Man sensation.

Pros

Story: Among the myriad Spider-Man tales, this game stands out as the best narrative rendition of the iconic superhero. Yuri Lowenthal brings Peter Parker to life with an amicable charm, infusing the character with dorky humor and a genuine love for his close ones. The development of the main villain, particularly the complex relationship between Doc Oc and Peter, adds emotional depth. Heartwarming connections with secondary characters enhance the storytelling. The action scenes, masterfully filmed, are not just exhilarating but can also leave you breathless.

Gameplay: The game successfully captures the essence of being Spider-Man. Swinging through the city feels rewarding and is so satisfying that fast travel becomes an afterthought. The velocity and wind while swinging contribute to the authentic Spider-Man experience. Combat, especially in the highest difficulty, demands effective use of gadgets, creating a superhero feel. Achieving big combos, executing perfect dodges, and sending enemies flying make you not just a superhero but specifically Spider-Man.

Would-building: New York City feels alive and authentic, bustling with life on its streets. The level of detail, whether swinging across rooftops or exploring the streets on foot, is remarkable. Interiors, despite mixed feelings about MJ and Miles stealth missions, showcase intricate design, encouraging players to slow down and appreciate the details.

Music: John Paesano's musical composition elevates the game to superheroic heights. The score is on par with the Avengers, reflecting inspiration from the iconic team. The music effectively enhances the sense of Spider-Man being a genuine superhero, balancing heroism with humility.

Cons

Open World: While the open-world design impresses with its attention to detail, the accompanying mechanics introduce a drawback. Secondary missions, such as bases and city crimes, become overly repetitive. Even with slight variations for different factions, the core gameplay remains unchanged. The monotony can make these missions feel like a tedious chore, especially when striving for 100% completion. The fighting mechanics help alleviate this to some extent, but the repetitiveness becomes a noticeable flaw.

Summary: "Marvel’s Spider-Man" emerges as a stellar action game, seamlessly blending a compelling narrative with a meticulously crafted Spider-Man experience. The game excels in presenting a superb main character, a gripping story, and unparalleled mobility. For me, it stands as the epitome of the Spider-Man gaming experience.

Game looks really good and mostly runs really good on PC. And it is one of the best Spider-Man games available to play. Period. But I just hit a glitch that corrupted my save so that I CTD whenever I try to continue my game, I can't! And I guess this game only keeps the one autosave on file so I'm fucked. So there goes four fucking hours. Anyway, I'm sick of shit not working, so I'm going to use my drop in the bucket to fuck with this games ratios. 

Seriously, what chucklefuck decided it would be a good idea to hinge and entire profile's progress on a SINGLE autosave file? I know multiples can exist! I've scrolled through PAGES of the fuckers on games old enough to legally adopt this one. Yet in a game where there are options to color-code different enemy types in the menu, I guess keeping a log of like, the five most recent autosaves is too tall an order?

I'll still beat the game. And I'll enjoy it. But this is just...an extremely upsetting oversight.

This is by far, the best superhero game i have played. the story is incredible and the combat system, while definitely has a learning curve to use everything at your disposal effectively, is fluid and satisfying. swinging around new york is always a blast and mastering the various swinging mechanics is extremely rewarding. the remastered graphics look amazing as well and the view of new york from the top of the empire state building is stunning to say the least.

That being said, there were a couple negatives. throughout my play-though, the game did save in a state where a had to revert back to an old save, losing a little bit of progress, in order to launch the game successfully. that being said however, my pc specs aren't the best so it very well could have been a me problem. overall though, as long as you make manual saves often and can power through a couple crashes, this game is a must play for any spider man fan and i would definitely recommend it even if you have never met Peter Parker

Spider-Man Remastered swings onto the gaming scene with a triumphant return, showcasing the beloved web-slinger in a polished and upgraded form. This reimagined version of the original Spider-Man for the PlayStation 4 brings not only a visual facelift but also subtle enhancements that elevate the overall experience, making it a must-play for both fans of the original and newcomers alike.

The first and most noticeable improvement in Spider-Man Remastered lies in its visuals. The game has undergone a stunning makeover, with enhanced graphics that take full advantage of the PlayStation 5's capabilities. The cityscape of New York has never looked more vibrant and alive, with detailed textures, improved lighting effects, and a level of realism that immerses players in the bustling metropolis like never before. The character models, especially Spider-Man's suit, showcase a level of detail that is a testament to the power of next-gen hardware.

The performance boost is equally impressive. Spider-Man Remastered runs at a smooth 60 frames per second, providing a buttery-smooth web-swinging experience that enhances the fluidity and responsiveness of the controls. The fast-paced action sequences, acrobatic combat, and seamless transitions between exploration and combat benefit greatly from the improved frame rate, making every swing and punch feel more dynamic and satisfying.

The addition of ray tracing is another standout feature, bringing an extra layer of realism to the reflective surfaces of the city and the glossy sheen of Spider-Man's suit. The ray-traced reflections contribute to the overall visual fidelity, creating a more immersive and visually stunning rendition of New York City.

Beyond the technical upgrades, Spider-Man Remastered includes a thoughtful assortment of additional content. The three new suits, each with unique abilities, provide a fresh take on Spidey's wardrobe and add a layer of excitement for players familiar with the original game. The inclusion of the photo mode allows players to capture and share their favorite in-game moments, showcasing the game's breathtaking visuals in a more personal way.

Despite these enhancements, Spider-Man Remastered remains true to the essence of the original game. The engaging narrative, well-developed characters, and the thrill of swinging through the iconic New York City skyline are preserved, ensuring that the heart and soul of the original experience are not lost in the remaster.

In conclusion, Spider-Man Remastered successfully combines the nostalgia of the original with the cutting-edge capabilities of the PlayStation 5. It's not just a visual upgrade; it's a celebration of the timeless appeal of Spider-Man as a gaming icon. Whether you're revisiting the adventures of Peter Parker or swinging into the Spider-Verse for the first time, Spider-Man Remastered is a spectacular journey that showcases the best of what the web-slinger has to offer in the next generation of gaming.

It is definitely worth 35 dollars I paid for it this winter sale.

Spiderman Gameplay: All of that being said the game is fantastic. Web slinging feels amazing, story is very good, fighting is good as well. The fighting does feel a little repetitive after awhile but as long as you mix up your attacks and wheel of spidey gadgets it'll keep it feeling alive for much longer. The side missions feel rewarding, like you're actually helping everyday citizens instead of stopping the city from literally being leveled. 

Miles/MJ Gameplay: Ok yeah its not as fun as being Spiderman, that's a given. However you do feel much more powerless because you've been relying on being able to beat people up with the might of Zeus. It is decently linear (some sections you have an open area but it all goes to the same place), and when MJ and Spiderman team up and you're directing Spiderman take downs. It feels very satisfying to do.

Overall: 9/10. Minus 1 for  repetitive feel of combat after a decent chunk of time (but it is still satisfying).

This Marvel Spider-Man game can be regarded as the pinnacle and benchmark of superhero genre games. The intricate city design and exquisite modeling fully showcase Sony's profound expertise in gaming. The classic high pricing may understandably deter some players, but who can resist the joy of swinging through the steel forest? Without a doubt, I would give a full score for the innovative controls. In terms of combat, it may seem a bit monotonous at the beginning, but as the game progresses, more fighting skills are developed. The storyline is authentic, rivaling the experience of watching a Spider-Man movie. The only aspect below my expectations is the somewhat tedious design of late-game activities, with dozens of scattered tasks causing a sense of confusion. Overall rating: 8/10.

This is one of the only games I've ever committed to getting all the achievements, so after having experienced everything it has to offer I can say that it's worth buying. I loved playing this game. That said, there are a few things that really drag it down.

The biggest one for me was the inconsistent writing. I will say that I do think they managed to write a good plot. Though it wasn't anything revolutionary, it definitely had its moments and I did enjoy it overall. However, there were multiple times where they undermine story's credibility for no absolutely reason. Without any spoilers, one example of this is SM's Spidey-Sense selectively not working, either to allow a side-character to save him, or to showcase a new antagonist. Often times it came off as an attempt to promote a strong female character, however it achieved the opposite effect due to it seeming forced. Strangely enough, there was one female character who was absolutely amazing, so they clearly know how to do it. Which makes it even more baffling that the female lead was so bland and needed blatant plot armor to be even slightly useful.
Another example of the story really dropping in quality is also due to the aforementioned female lead. She plays a large part in the story, and out of all the scenes she appears in there are maybe two or three in which she isn't whining about something or other. The incessant complaining really starts to get annoying and there is no way to make it stop since you HAVE to listen to the phone calls.
It's a real shame that there were so many great characters here, but one of the most important ones was just so insufferable.

When it comes to the combat mechanics, they knocked it out of the park. They did an incredible job of making Spiderman feel powerful. His many different abilities you can use in combination with each other allow for many different play-styles and strategies. The web-swinging aspect also felt spectacular. Traversing the map never got boring, to the point where I never even used the fast travel.
The thing is, they put so much effort into Spidey himself that I think they lost focus on the rest of the game. Regarding the enemies, there are essentially only five variations with different costumes on depending on who the main antagonist is at that point in the story. The combat ended up feeling a bit boring by the end of it, just because of how repetitive the enemies were. I also am of the opinion that aside from the street thugs, there shouldn't be any enemies walking around without weapons, since it just doesn't make sense, and even they should at least have pocket knives. All in all I think they could have done a better job. I will say however that this doesn't extend to the boss fights, all of which were unique and challenging.
The open world is in a similar situation. It appears great initially, with great visuals and many collectibles and side-quests, but as you play you realize how empty it is. Once you have completed all the side-quests and secondary objectives, there is literally nothing to do in this game aside from stopping the same three or four crimes over and over. On top of that, most of these secondary objectives aren't even fun to begin with. Most of them consist of collecting the same object x amount of times, and don't even get me started on the Screwball missions. To say they are infuriating is an understatement, and one of the later ones is literally impossible to do properly if you purchased a certain upgrade, which you definitely will have done by then as it's near the end of the last DLC. I think they could have put in more of an effort to make the world feel alive.

Overall this is a great game, however I think it's slightly too expensive for the price, since the most you're going to get out of it is around 50 hours of gameplay, and that's if you complete all the side missions too. Despite its flaws I did really enjoy this game though, and I definitely recommend it.

Fast paced combat, smooth traversal, beautiful visuals. and a decent story. The main campaign is the perfect length but the remastered edition comes with three story DLCs. Each one focuses on a female character after the main campaign: Black Cat, Yuri Watanabe, and Silver Sable respectively. I didn't do all the side content for the DLCs but their stories were good so I finished the main path for each even though at that stage I was a but burnt out on it.

Very late to the party on this one, but just reaffirming what everyone else has already said. Outside of the OG GTA games, this might be the most satisfying sandbox game I’ve ever played, simply because the traversing is so damn good. Web swinging from building to building in classic Spider-man form, heading to new missions, challenges, or Spider-man lore side quests was extremely fun. Insomniac has a winning formula here which probably was borrowed and modified from the Arkham games. If you have been patiently waiting for the next Batman Arkham game, this just might check all your boxes. Oh, and it plays wonderfully on the deck. 

Obviously will be checking out the stand alone Miles game and Spider-man 2 when available.

This is a game that feels constantly at odds with itself, trying to do too many different things at once and only succeeding at a select few. The swinging is by far the best thing out of this entire package. While I don't think the swinging is AS free flowing as Spider-man 2 on the GameCube, it has some nice flow to it and requires a lot of finesse to get down so I'm very much satisfied with it. Everything else though...not so much.

The combat is...fine I guess. It feels more comparable to a watered-down hack and slash if anything else. You get a very small handful of moves to start out with (exactly one grounded combo, a launcher, and an air combo) and a few more smaller techniques added on later. It "works" yeah, but there's just not a whole lot of variety, and the game essentially brow beats you into air combo-ing everything in sight over and over again because that's the best way to clear rooms in an effective way. It deals more damage, it charges focus faster, it makes a vast majority of enemies helpless, and it just gets stale after a while. The bosses aren't anything to write home about and the enemy variety is sorely lacking. The gadgets aren't well implemented in combat either and a lot of them just feel like they're there for the sake of being there. There's only so much joy I can mine from cannonball kicking the same faceless goon for the umpteenth time before I lose interest and go back to swinging around the city.

The stealth sections don't get any praise however, they SUUUUCK. These try and ape off the Arkham predator sections without understanding what made these sections work to begin with: enemy AI, level design, and tension. All of which Marvel's Insomniac's Disney's Stan Lee's Spider-Man spectacularly fails at. There's no thought or strategy behind any of these sections, they feel so forced and tacked on and utterly dull, and what makes it worse is that after you clear the room by stealth takedown-ing everyone the game just spawns enemies in already alerted to your presence anyway so like...what exactly was the point in using stealth to begin with? The MJ and Miles sections bring the pace of the game to a screeching halt. They aren't fun or interesting, they're the generic "sneak behind bushes and throw distraction items to avoid being instakilled" stealth gameplay that's already been done to death (and done better) in a variety of other games. 

The open world isn't even fun to explore either. It's filled to the brim with the typical open world busywork schlock; copy pasted enemy base assaults, radio towers, collectibles spewed everywhere. Even when I have this desire to pick the game back up again I'm reminded that outside of the swinging, there's nothing here for me to really enjoy.

The nicest things I can say about it is that it looks really nice and it's competently put together. That's really about it. I would hope the sequels do a much better job at innovating and improving what didn't work prior but judging from gameplay footage, not really. Quite a shame

Even tho I wasn't a fan of the game, I would recommend it. The action is nice and some missions are really cool. Is not a long game; If you focus only on main missions and skip cinematics, the game is 4 or 5 hours long, which is a bit dissapointing. I hated all the parts where you have to use MJ or Miles. They felt stupid and unnecesary. Also they break the pacing of the game, quite a lot. Sadly, for what I heard, it is a trait that perdured in the following titles. Lastly, both in the DLC and NG+, the times between main missions where you have "dead time" for patrolling the city until the next mission triggers, felt like stupid move. They could have chained all side missions without down time in between and it would have been the same.

The side missions and map objecitves, some are ok and some aren't. The "crimes" felt like a chore and weren't engaing enough to keep me interested in them. Same happened with the side missions of the missing students from ESU. In contrast, Taskmaster tasks, the landmarks and even catching the pidgeons are more entertaining and fun.

About the story, it is a nice one, with a very complete gallery of rogues. Somehow, this is the second (or third?) time that I hate MJ's character in a Spider-Man portrayal. They make her so unlikeable that it even feels weird that Peter still goes after her. I saw more connection with Felicia in the DLC. About those, Ep1 and 3 were ok-ish enough, Ep2 was a snooze fest. Besides that, having completing 100% of the main story before going to the DLC makes the side objectives of it a complete waste of time, since you are already full upgraded in every aspect. They could have added a few things in here, to keep it interesting (or some sort of unlockable action), but no, you esentially slugh through the DLC and NG+ without anything "new" besides some suits. About the suits, it's a nice thing to have, also the combinable powers; but not all have the same quality, imo.

The achievements weren't hard to get, pretty straight forward. While doing the second run for the NG+, I didn't get why some cinematics are skippable and some not; my guess is for it to be a bit longer that it actually is. 

Anyway, I liked a few things, and I hated a lot more, so my opinion may be controversial, but is barely a 5. Having played games like the Arkham series (which this game is heavily inspired of), this one falls short.

Помню как я, будучи мелким, в середине нулевых ходил с братом в компьютерный клуб, где мой брат играл в КС или Варкрафт, а я в Spider-man 2. Хотя полет на паутине в той игре был супер примитивным (там висели такие паутинки между зданиями и только за них можно было цепляться), мне безумно нравилось летать по Нью-Йорку и проходить неимоверно сложные, как мне тогда казалось, миссии. Игра делала невозможное возможным давая возможность прикинуть на себя роль дружелюбного соседа и надрать задницу Доктору Октавиусу. Это было своего рода магией для тогдашнего меня. Кто бы мог подумать, что спустя 20 лет, эта магия никуда не исчезнет и я снова смогу ощутить себя Человеком-пауком в похожей игре, но уже с более интересным сюжетом, постановкой и по-настоящему живыми персонажами. Питер тут прям как надо - обаятельный и остроумный добряк, который готов пожертвовать самым дорогим ради спасения людей. По игре видно, что люди, которые её создавали, очень любят этого персонажа и дорожат им. Не часто можно увидеть такое бережное отношение к популярным героям и их фанатам. Очень порадовало наличие разных костюмов, в особенности тех, что из фильмов. Так приятно иногда надеть костюм из трилогии с Тоби и, летая по Нью-Йорку, понастальгировать по детству. В общем, игра супер, всем рекомендую.

My favorite Batman game, not the BEST, that goes to City. But it is my FAVORITE of the trilogy (yes I mean trilogy. I don't count Origins). It looks spectacular, better than even some CURRENT games, Rocksteady has mastered the glorious combat mechanics with some new welcome editions. While yes, the Bat-mobile v tanks was a little excessive, I didn't mind too much because it was still fun to drive around in the badass ride. While the bossfights weren't as great as City's, they were still fun and amazing, Pyg, Man-bat, Riddler, Penguin, and the 3 jokers were standouts in my opinion. Speaking of the bosses, the designs for them are better than ever. Scarecrow is legitimately terrifying at certain times, and his voice actor did an absolutely amazing job. Pyg looks horrifying, and the way he speaks is just disturbing and really sells that he thinks he's doing people a favor. Man-bat looks like he should, a realistic blend of man and bat, his lifeless looking eyes, and teeth, the way he screeches making it sound like he's in pain and doesn't know where to go is just heartbreaking. The rest look great too, Deathstroke, Firefly, Two-Face, Joker, Azrael, all don't have too significant changes, but still look spectacular. There is one character I haven't mentioned yet, the Arkham Knight. While I knew who he was as soon as he said he had a history with Batman, and just his attitude overall, I knew who he was. But even then, it was still sad to see. It wasn't surprising who he was, but how he felt and his motivation was indeed surprising. You believe him, you feel his side of the story. I don't wanna spoil for people who haven't played, so that's all I'm gonna say. 
The heroes along side Batman are also super cool, Nightwing's design is super badass, and the metallic blue emblem that goes around his chest and back is really cool. While Robin isn't SUPER prominent, he still looks awesome, with the shaved head, the brighter suit since City, and trading the dark green gloves and boots for black looks way better. Oracle, Alfred, Jim Gordon, Cash, Lucius Fox, they all look great, if not too different (well, except Lucius, who made his first appearance in the game). Batman REALLY shines though, the first suit you start with looks great, and then you get upgraded to the ULTIMATE BAT-SUIT. It looks SO GOOD, and they explain why it makes sense, science! YEAH! The suit's features really make you feel like you're the Dark Knight himself, I won't spoil anything, but it really is a feast for the eyes. 

Overall, the game, while flawed, is a superb game, and an even better Batman game. Maybe not the best in Arkham series, but definitely the one I play the most, and the one I will without a doubt, call my favorite.

Honestly, really great game. ...In the overworld, at least. The story it tells is great, but there is a huge over-reliance on Quick Time Events during segments that would otherwise be fun. And most every story event has scripted requirements of how things go down, which makes playing your way feel kinda pointless. You spend so much time stealthily picking off enemies during base missions, only for the wave battles to trigger no matter what you do. And the late-game/post-game enemies can counter most of your moves, so creatively taking down hordes of enemies becomes less possible/satisfying as the game goes on.

I really did enjoy my time with this game, but my enjoyment diminished pretty sharply from the last chapter and onto DLC. Great mechanics and gameplay, when the game itself isn't limiting them.

1. The Good: This game does indeed give you the Spider Man experience you always wanted. The combat is fun and easy to learn. A large arsenal of cool gadgets and a extensive skill tree for your favorite web head. The story here is actually really good for a video game and the boss fights were fun and emotionally engaging. The web swinging is unbelievably good and one of the best parts of the game. Lots of side content after the main story. The skins and upgrades/mods are really fun to unlock and play with. 

2. The Bad: The basic enemies can get a little repetitive. While there is a lot of side quests, some of it is repetitive, boring, and tedious (I'd say the large majority is). The enemy AI isn't very good or in depth at all but it's still fun regardless. Overall definitely worth getting even at a higher price.

3. The DLC: Some of the content is good and some of it boring. I found the stories to be very meh. I enjoyed the Black Cat story line a good amount. Hammerhead was a interesting character in the first DLC pack and a great boss fight, but they definitely dragged him along into the other packs and he got old fast. Silver Sable was kind of meh and a lot of the game play is identical to the first game and isn't introducing anything new. These DLCs add a lot of side content but it's all pretty standard repetitive, boring side missions with little to no story connection. Also I hate you Screwball.

So, "Marvel's Spider-Man Remastered" on Steam? Good. Swinging through the city is crazy fun, especially with the upgraded graphics, lightning and ray tracing. It looks sharp and beautiful, and New York is like a playground.

Fighting bad guys is also good. Spidey's got moves, and the combat feels smooth but it can get repetitive. The story is on point – it's got that superhero drama and action and everything comes together amazingly, even when you add up the DLCs. Voice acting ain't too shabby either.

And hey, talking about DLCs, they bundled in all the extra content, so that's a win. No need to nickel and dime for DLC.

Overall, if you're into Spider-Man or just want a solid action game, this one's worth a go. It's not reinventing the wheel, but it spins it damn well. Go swing around and have some fun. That is granted.

Also spoiler ahead: [spoiler]Black Cat >>>>> MJ [/spoiler]

The closest replica to the original Spider-man 2 on the then PlayStation 2. Marvels Spider-man is a exceptional game with a great story, fun combat& gadgets, interesting side stories and 3 great DLC's. I had so much fun just swinging through
the city and occasionally throwing a web bomb in a jewelers shop pasting the walls in web and all the thugs that were unsuccessfully trying to rob it. The game feels alive, there is always something to catch your eye and there is always something to do. If anything, you will not be bored.
I had 3 crashes in my 48hrs played, not many, but at the same time I was expecting zero. There was also frame drops every now and then which would cause me to have to reboot the game. I also saw people 20ft above the air at one point but I just said meh and moved on.

Achievements: Mostly collectibles and side objectives that you can do when you want a break from the main story. If your going for 100% completion you will get everything in time nor can you miss anything so relax and just play the game with your leisure. The same applies to the DLC.

9.5/10 The crashes and performance hurt it slightly, but Spider-man is still a fantastic game. Can't wait for No.2 to be ported just so that I can hear more of Jonah Jamesons egging, grumpy old fart.

Marvel's Spider-Man Remastered: 55 hours, 100% completion. Insomniac's visual marvel and gameplay finesse redefine Spidey's world. An epic journey, seamlessly blending nostalgia and innovation.

[b] Story - 7.5/10 [/b]
Main story: a web of fun and engagement. DLCs, though, lack the same thrill, feeling a bit lackluster in comparison

[b] Graphics and Sound - 8.5/10 [/b]
The detail of Manhattan is pretty amazing, lighting looks stunning and the raytracing reflections are noticable and run surprisingly well even on AMD GPUs.
The music and sound effects are pretty decent too.

[b] Gameplay and Mechanics - 9.5/10 [/b]
The webswinging is really smooth and the mechanics are overall pretty good.

[b] Playtime - 9/10 [/b]
Just the main story should take approximately 10h, 100% completion including all DLCs takes about 45h-60h.

[b] Difficulty - 7.5/10 [/b]
The main game is pretty easy, even on the highest difficulty. The second and third DLC are way harder but still doable.
Overall an easy to average game in terms of diffculty.

[b] Achievements 10/10 [/b]
Very doable, not too boring, too hard or grindy.
As is said, 45h-60h for 100% completion.
Helpful guide: https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2847994141

[b] Performance and Bugs 7/10 [/b]
I had some crashes and smaller bugs, but overall not too annoying.
Optimization for PC is good, especially for a console to PC port.

[b] Overall rating 8/10 [/b]

After 56 hours, I have finally finished the game, including all the DLCs. I'm a huge fan of the Spiderman movies and Marvel itself. This kept me glued to my seat for hours. An outstanding game, and one of the best superhero narratives out there, really. Comparable with Arkham City in terms of the depth of storytelling and the freeflow combat. But while Batman's primary moves consist of punch and counter, Spiderman's are punch and dodge. He doesn't have a "counter" move as such, but is instead all about being quicker than the enemy and attacking from different angles.

Swinging through the city is also possibly the most enjoyable way to traverse a game world (at least until the sequel arrives on PC). 

Performance was flawless on my RTX 2060, and load times almost non-existent. The definition of an excellent PC port.

A shockingly heartfelt and emotional story with absolutely transcendent movement mechanics. This is probably the closest thing we will get to a Gravity Rush 3. The presentation when things get trippy are fantastic and the ending has some of the most emotional acting I've seen in a videogame. Loved it way more than I was anticipating given this is a super hero game.

Why not a 5 star imo:
my only real complaint is that literally 20 seconds after one crime gets solved, another one is already popping up. Like, I get that in the third act it should feel like chaos and like the city is falling apart, but going from one copied event to another so quickly just feels crowded and not necessarily deep.

Also I didn't love the MJ/Miles stealth sections. I don't mind playing as other characters with different mechanics, and I get that they were probably trying to remind players that Spiderman is a super hero by making you play as a normal human in a world lead by super villains, but they still felt kinda clunky and padded compared to how polished everything spiderman was.

Definitely worth picking up on a good sale. Worth $30-40 USD I'd say

I am a fan of Spider-Man since I was a kid, so maybe my opinion about Spider-Man games may not be very objective.

Even so. I really love Spider-Man games. The ability to web-swing around the city is the most fun aspect of Spider-Man games that no other game has been able to replicate up to this day. So games like Ultimate Spider-Man, Web of Shadows and others are among my favorites despite their flaws.

And now I have a chance to play Marvel's Spider-Man, and I gotta say, it's significantly better than all the other Spider-Man games. I'm so happy that Insomniac put in such an incredible amount of effort to make this game, because everything so far has been so fun and enjoyable for me: story, characters, voice over, gameplay, music, atmosphere...

I definitely recommend this game to people that like Spider-Man, enjoy games of superhero genre and/or games with free-roaming.

I wish there was a % score for these ratings. Thumbs up or down option just isn’t accurate enough. This game is like a ¾ thumb. When it’s in full swing it’s AMAZING! But then it's lows are totally cringe. When you’re zipping around fighting crime and solving stuff as spiderman the game is at it highest points! But when you must play the stupid side plots quests as MJ or when you even must talk to her it’s so bad. Make an MJ game and give people the option to play that if you think it needs to be done. But to strong arm her into this game felt forced for DEI score. Her dialog is eye rolling and I just wanted her to stop talking every time she was around, all she does is gaslight peter for being a hero and not putting her needs first. IDK who wrote her but get a clue people. Miles is not far off from this, he’s very whiny, and he's hard to relate to IMO but IDk maybe I'm just to old heh. Some of the highlights where aunt May who was very well written, she’s warm, kind and relatable. She feels like an actual person. I couldn’t help smiling whenever she was in a scene. Doc OC was another stand out too, you definitely get a feel for what he’s going through, very fleshed out. 

The combat is executing, even if it is just a one button mash. I liked it. It was hard on hard but not so hard that I wasn’t able to take in all the cool things going on around me while I was in the middle of it. The game play loop is good, towards the end of it I was starting to get a bit bogged down in doing the same kinda bases and chases repeatedly. The side content was definitely over kill in this area, some of these side missions are very bad.... I chased some pigeons? For a maybe homeless guy or something? idk very weird. I wanted to play the DLC for the story but they felt very bloated and bogged down with the same mechanics of main game but with out any of the substance of it. I think they problly released this way later originally? So maybe people would like getting back into the swing of things like this but as a full playthrough I would not recommend doing the dlc stuff. Just go watch some videos of the cut scenes.

Anyways there it is, IDK if it’s a hawt take or not just my thought. Good game not great.

Very fun game. Web slinging feels great especially with the skills you unlock. Combat is never boring, like sticking enemies too literally anything. Highly recommend buying this. Plus, all the DLC is included.

Marvel's Spider-Man Remastered is a really fun game that made me realize maybe not all modern AAA games are bad. 
Web-slinging feels great with a satisfying sense of momentum and speed, combat is fun and easy to understand and satisfying to throw enemies around. Story isn't sophisticated top-tier kino but it is interesting and fun to follow. There are also a lot of fun costumes to unlock from a plethora of other Spider-Man media and collectibles that give you little lore tidbits (and more costumes!). Most costumes even come with abilities that let you do wacky stuff during combat that either make the game easier, difficult, or silly (and can be used on any costume!) Gadgets are fun but some are way-too over-powered (will talk about that a bit later.). This game is also really fun to get all achievements in (hint: The statue of liberty is a photo location and isn't very obvious, do that first when you get to it.). Also the DLC missions though relatively brief, are really fun and have some cool stuff to unlock

Now for cons and nitpicks:

This game crashed for me a LOT while fast-traveling on Windows. There have been some other crashes during random events but most are due to fast-travel. Thankfully it's pretty fun to just swing places instead but it is still a very annoying bug that has existed far too long. Also there are some stealth sections in the game where you play as MJ or Miles Morales (before the cool Spider powers) and it really disrupts the flow of the game. The segments aren't horrendous but get very annoying on subsequent playthroughs.

About performance, this game should be playable on just about anything from the past 10 years that isn't a Chromebook, you just may need to use FSR for a playable framerate on older GPUs. I had issues maintaining 60fps at native resolution no upscaling on my GTX 1660ti but I think I really abused that poor thing in the past. Game runs well on Steam Deck too with fair performance and visuals. Just enable FSR with a fps target of 30. More info is on ProtonDB. There is a weird graphical bug on Steam Deck (maybe Linux/amd cards in general?) where moving the camera will smear certain objects, I do not know what causes this as I've tried every setting. If you have a decent GPU though, this game is BEAUTIFUL. Even without raytracing (do not use unless you are made of money for your own sanity, the game looks great without it)

TL:DR, great game that's hours of fun with some technical issues that aren't game ruining and tedious segments that are annoying when replaying the game

Best game I have played in while!

This time simply "No".

After the first 7 hours of uninterrupted fun, I was already thinking about complaining only a little bit but still giving it a thumbs-up, however, despite not changing the previous settings, I've been getting one crash to desktop after another every 30 to 60 minutes for several sessions. Curiously, after progressing into the story a bit, and not changing anything in the settings, the issue disappeared...

As for the game itself:

Pros:
- The story is okay. Nothing groundbreaking, good old Spider-man
- The environment looks amazing
- A lot of settings to choose from
- Can turn off QTEs
- A lot of mentions of the "older" material and events
- Web-slinging through the city is masterfully done. Full trajectory control via mouse movements, the feeling of building speed. (But...)
- Most side missions and exploration activities and goals are fun, often accompanied with an interesting commentary from MC

Cons:
- Combat feels clunky and not properly optimized - MC is limited by certain animations, resulting in some moves not working like you would expect
- The character feels far too squishy (I know he's no Hulk, nor Iron-man, but still...)
- the stealth segments (of side characters) are pointless
- The ranked challenge missions are terrible. I don't mind trying to improve my high-score, but here it's about combating the clunky controls and trying to guess how the character will move on his own during parkour
- few moments where the terrain textures obstructed my field of vision during combat
- after playing through most of the main story, I can't shake the feeling that despite the details, the characters are often quite... soulless, empty and stiff

Other than the above, I can't shake the feeling it's a strange mix of Batman games and Prototype 2 with just a texture of Spider-man, but with its own dose of unoptimized faults.

At first I could just reload and get the game running like normal. But then it started crashing completely with every loading screen and every fast travel. And trying to restart the game takes 3-5 tries before the game actually runs. It's impossible to get immersion when I get kicked out for 20-30 minutes every time I need to reload. 

I waited a week before writing this review because I made a support ticket. The forum is full of people with the same problem. I was hoping someone would respond and fix the problems but it is apparent that they don't care.

Edit: I did eventually fix it with help from another gamer. No answer from the company about that ticket.

It's a great game. However, when you get deep into the game, it crashes a lot. It crashes when you load your game. It crashes when you use quick travel. That, in itself, would not be terrible. It also seems to save a corrupted version of your game, and when you try to load it, it crashes. That's the auto save. And, inevitably, it's the manual save as well. 

I thought I'd solved the problem, but no, it crashes, the saved game doesn't work, and I'm more than 75% done the game. A quick search online reveals that MANY people are having this same problem. It is beyond frustrating to get that far into a game, lose your saved games, and either have to start over again, or give up. I chose to give up.

Until that is fixed, don't buy the game. It's fun, you would enjoy it, but it will slowly drive you insane. It cannot be finished in its current state, unless you manually save every time you accomplish anything, for fear of losing what you've accomplished.

Bizarrely, I had none of these issues with the Spider-Man: Miles Morales game, which is a sequel to this one. Not sure why. It worked fine and I really enjoyed it.

[h1]This is hands-down, one of the best games I have ever had the pleasure of experiencing. Spider-Man Remastered is truly a masterpiece.[/h1]
[b][u]RUNS PHENOMENALLY ON STEAM DECK AT 30+ FPS[/u][/b]
[i](There was an issue late in the second act where dialogue audio wouldn't play properly, but it didn't last more than a few minutes- easy to overlook and probably just a quirk of the Deck)[/i]

I purchased this game at a 33% discount, and I feel like I had a 5-Star meal, alongside a delicious after-course.

I've very stubborn when it comes to my decisions about which games to play, let-alone [b]continue[/b] playing after the initial boot. I know next to nothing about Marvel but this game had me absolutely hooked, on the edge of my seat to see what comes next. The emotional highs, lows, the writing, the interactions- the world, it's all so real and convincing. This game made me feel like a real superhero.

It's so refreshing for me to play a game that truly feels like it cut no corners. There's no missing context. No bossfights that end before they start. No glaring technical issues. No loose ends. The world is massive and yet I cannot recall encountering a single glitch- it's unbelievable how much love, care and time went in to polishing this game.

It took me 14 hours to reach the credits, and I am beyond satisfied with what I spent / what I received in return. I haven't even touched the DLCs yet.

If you're a Marvel fan, this is a must-play.
If you're [i]not[/i] a Marvel fan, but you like great movement, combat, and exciting story full of many twists and turns, then I urge you to try Spider-Man Remastered

Great game! 
Pros:
1. Amazing Graphics
2. Smooth Combat
3. Traversal options are good
4. Web-Swinging is safe but good enough to keep you enjoying it throughout the game
5. Story is decent with powerful emotional scenes
6. Good customisation options, you can make different builds with the suit mods and suit powers. 
7. Many alternative costumes

Cons:
1. The Combat gets quite repetitive, and while there are ways to make it more interesting, it is ultimately not enough to make you enjoy the combat fully throughout the entire game.
2. In certain story segments you are forced to play as other characters, and the Mary Jane segments are notoriously boring to get through. You can rush through them for the most part but they aren't fun. 

Overall a really enjoyable experience, you can complete all the achievements in about 50~ish hours, probably less if you speedrun.

Marvel's Spider-Man is a really solid game, but if I want to be honest I liked the Batman Arkham games more in the the "open world superhero genre".

Traversing the city of New York using Spidey's web slinging abilities is definitely the best part of the game, the movements are very fluid, and it's super fun, I never got bored of it. The combat is also really enjoyable, it can get really versatile if you utilize all the gadgets, moves, suit powers.

The story starts a little too slow in my opinion (though by the end it gets more and more interesting), and the side quests are kinda meh, it would have been great to see more supervillains with longer storylines instead of investigating fake Spiderman sightings, catching pigeons and whatnot.

Overall it's still the best Spider-Man game I have ever played, so I'm excited about the continuation of the story, but I expected a little more.

Genuinely might be my favourite game I ever played on steam (even prompted me to buy a ps5 just to play its sequel), whether you might be a Marvel fan or even just a fan of open world games in general this is one of the best you ever would play I guarantee it. Same with the combat since I found myself relying so much on the gadgets to get past enemies with any form of blocking and it felt a lot more repetitive than I remembered compared to the sequel which had symbiote and venom abilities as well as a charged attack all built off of combos and gadgets felt a lot more effective there too, as well as parrying meaning I can just dodge or attack off of an enemy. Either way this still is an amazing game despite its flaws

One of the most beautiful stories I've ever witnessed in my life . This game truly makes you feel like you're Spider_Man  at all times . "Swinging Into Nostalgia and Innovation: Spider-Man Remastered Delivers a Spectacular Experience"

I recently had the pleasure of diving back into the web-slinging world with Spider-Man Remastered, and I can confidently say that this revamped version of the classic game is nothing short of amazing.

From the moment I swung into action as Peter Parker, I was captivated by the stunning graphics and attention to detail. The remastered edition has breathed new life into New York City, making it a vibrant and dynamic playground for our friendly neighborhood Spider-Man. The level of detail in the character models, cityscape, and even the smallest details like reflections in puddles truly showcase the power of next-gen gaming.

One of the standout features for me was the improved performance. The seamless transition between fast-paced web-swinging and intense combat is a testament to the technical prowess of the developers. The enhanced frame rate and reduced loading times kept me immersed in the action, eliminating any disruptions and allowing for a more fluid and enjoyable gaming experience.

The addition of the three new suits, inspired by Spider-Man's comic book legacy, adds a delightful touch of nostalgia for long-time fans. It's not just a visual treat, though; each suit comes with its own unique abilities, adding a layer of strategy to the gameplay. Whether I was taking on waves of enemies or soaring through the city skyline, these new suits brought an extra dimension to the already fantastic gameplay.

The reworked lighting and ray tracing effects deserve special mention. The play of shadows across the city, the way the sunlight reflects off Spider-Man's suit – it all contributes to an immersive and visually stunning experience. Exploring the city at different times of day became a joy in itself, as the dynamic lighting created breathtaking scenes that showcased the game's attention to realism.

Beyond the technical upgrades, Spider-Man Remastered stays true to the heart of the original game. The engaging narrative, compelling characters, and the emotional journey of Peter Parker are as impactful as ever. The talented voice cast, coupled with the enhanced facial animations, brings these characters to life in a way that's both authentic and emotionally resonant.

In conclusion, Spider-Man Remastered is a triumph in both nostalgia and innovation. Insomniac Games has not only successfully revitalized a beloved classic but has also set a new standard for what a remastered edition can achieve. Whether you're a longtime fan or swinging into the Spider-Verse for the first time, this game is an absolute must-play. It's a celebration of everything that makes Spider-Man great, and it does justice to the iconic character in every web-slinging moment.

Spider-Man Remastered on Steam is simply amazing! The graphics are jaw-dropping, making swinging through New York City a visual treat. The controls are super smooth, and the combat feels even more epic than before.

The game includes all the DLC, so you get a ton of content to enjoy. The story keeps you hooked, and the voice acting is top-notch. Plus, the photo mode is a blast – capturing those action-packed moments is too much fun!

If you loved the original or are new to Spider-Man games, this remastered version is a must-play. It's like experiencing the thrill of being Spidey for the first time, and it's hands down one of the best superhero games out there. Swing into action and don't miss out on the fun!
