This is almost a perfect port of the game with little issues, but the scale of these issues is quite high. I'll list some right away:

1. Doing instant takedowns gets bugged a lot. You need to pause and un-pause the game to fix it. Happens way too often and in your first playthrough where you're trying to get used to the combat system, it can be super jarring and make you think you are legit messing up. It can also lead you to taking BS hits because your take down didn't go off, and I even died once or twice because of it. But it isn't a deal breaker because you can learn to recognize it over time.
2. I have no idea if this was my controller (Xbox One Controller - Brand New Wired), or the game, but there were occasions where the controller would just stop working randomly. Full stop, and I have no idea what causes it. Hell, one time Spiderman just started moving forward on his own and I couldn't do anything about it. However, this only happened once or twice within 50 hours of gameplay. 
3. Wall crawling on specific terrain can lead you to be trapped within a building, which you obviously aren't meant to be. This forces you to restart from your checkpoint, only happened once with me though. 
4. Freezing and crashing isn't abundant per say, but it did happen often enough for me to grow exasperated. A handful of times. Thankfully, the game is quick to start up and the checkpoint system is very good, so you will rarely lose any real progress in or out of missions. 
5. The most important issue and is honestly game breaking is the save corruption issue. This, in my experience, was caused by a certain side mission by [spoiler] Taskmaster [/spoiler]. Sometimes, upon restarting the mission due to failure or just wanting to do so on your own, the game will instantly crash at the loading screen. Normally, this would not be an issue and you would just load back in, but it literally CORRUPTS your save. To save it, you have to do lots of nonsense with your files and it's total horse shit. The fact that this even exists is ridiculous. People could legit lose all their progress in one fell swoop if they aren't computer savvy enough to fix it. Even if you do all that stuff to fix it, you basically have to just avoid that mission like the plague and pray that when you come back to it (for achievements), that it won't do it again. Thankfully, it didn't happen again to me, but it pissed me off heavily. It says a lot that I still recommend this game even with this in it. 

Other than that, the game is pretty great:
Visuals on PC are stunning if your computer can handle it. The story is passable but nothing you wouldn't expect from a Spiderman game or movie. Voice acting is fine as well, but Spiderman's quips during side missions can repeat often if you do a ton of side missions back to back, which sometimes makes me wish he would shut the hell up. Combat is a little awkward to get used to if you are coming from the Batman Arkham games, but it is somewhat similar with the addition of the acrobatics that Spiderman is known for. Swinging through the city feels great and you can fast travel to avoid trips that are a bit too long. 

There are sections where you play as two other characters other than Peter Parker which basically amount to "avoid enemies and get through the stealth level". On your first playthrough, these are harmless and end relatively quickly if you aren't impatient and get caught over and over again. But on repeat playthroughs, they suck ass and just drag. But since you beat it already, you can get through the level very quickly. People online threw them lots of shit but they aren't that bad.  

In terms of the DLC content, it's more of the same. Each one leads into the next so they aren't disconnected nothing stories. Everything matters. I only have two real complaints from them:

1. [spoiler] Silver Sable's [/spoiler] role in the third DLC seems really forced. She seemed to actually care at least a little bit about Spiderman's health in the main game before she basically just left the main story off screen. She was troubled but clearly seemed to be rethinking her approach on justice, a positive character change. However, in the third DLC where she returns, her character regresses heavily back into what it was at the start of the main story, which is baffling. The justification for this is that her home country is in a civil war, and it's taken a toll on her head, so she's high strung and stressed out. Not to mention the thugs in NYC are stealing her company's equipment which she needs to fight in the aforementioned war, so she's hell bent on getting it back. Understandable, but the problem arises when you see how she treats Spiderman as not only an ally, but a human being. She outright nearly kills him for this equipment, even as Spiderman outright tells her that he will help her with no strings attached. Granted, her and Spiderman were not friends by the end of the main story, but they were certainly not enemies. She stubbornly refuses his help and it only serves to create conflict for the plot, but it isn't organic. Spiderman has already gone through this song and dance with her in the main story. She has ALREADY placed her trust in him to get jobs done in the main story, so there is really zero reason for her to be so hostile towards him and refuse his help. And that takes up a lot of the plot in the last DLC and it basically wraps up soon after they team up. Hell, it doesn't even take much for her to be convinced. Again, the reasoning for the civil war causing her character change makes no sense in-universe, as it is outright stated that hostilities have been around for a long time, so it isn't like this is some crazy revelation and battles have occurred in the past.  I digress.

2. Screwball, as a character, is terrible. Yes, she is meant to be annoying and obnoxious. However, that doesn't mean it's okay for her to annoy the shit out of the player. If you fail to get the max score on her challenges and you want to ace them, you have to hear the same stupid lines repeated over and over again with horrible internet humor. If she was a one-off character, this wouldn't be a problem, but her missions last throughout all three DLCs. In the main story, she plays an extremely minor role so nobody minds, but she has lots of missions in the DLCs.

Visually stunning, the graphics overhaul is awe-inspiring. With enhanced textures, ray tracing, and improved lighting, swinging through the intricately detailed streets of New York feels like a whole new experience. The PC version takes full advantage of the platform, offering a level of visual fidelity that was previously unmatched.Performance on PC is exceptional, delivering a silky-smooth 60 frames per second, and load times are practically nonexistent. The game's core mechanics remain intact, providing the same exhilarating web-slinging and combat that fans fell in love with on console.
The addition of new suits and the enhanced photo mode add a fresh layer of excitement for both new and returning players. While the core gameplay remains unchanged, the PC release is a testament to the timeless appeal of Spider-Man's acrobatic feats.

In conclusion, Spider-Man Remastered for PC is a triumphant adaptation that not only meets but exceeds expectations. The visual and performance enhancements make this version a must-play for any fan of the friendly neighborhood superhero. Swinging through the city has never felt this good on PC.

Anyway, I'm having a blast and I definitely recommend this game.

Overwhelmingly positive indeed. Great graphics, even better gameplay. What they do very right is flow, which keeps the game enjoyable, exciting and replayable. Sure they could make it more technical with little pauses and excessive decision making, but that would take the fun out of it. They found a great balance,   with a great feel once the controls become intuitive, which doesn't take long. It has a long story, so much plot, so many villains, that it felt like they're leaving little material for a sequel. Can't wait to play #2 that just came out, hope it's on PC before long.

So much so, that I beat this game 8 times and I still find myself wanting to come back to this masterpiece. And if people have a hard time trying to decide whether or not it's worth it, lemme steer you into the right direction - get this game. You won't be disappointed.

You know the story of spider-man, we all know it all too well, don't need to explain it. If you don't got it, well, time to pick up a spidey comic. Have fun. 

Now this game sets this Peter in the prime time of his life, 8 years ahead since he first became Spider-Man, the best parts of his story with Peter struggling to keep his job, manage his love-life, try to avoid being evicted from his apartment, and being Spider-Man at the same time (Not many believe it, but all this *is* the prime of his life, the best stories are the ones that merge both worlds from Peter and Spider-Man, and the struggles the characters face). This Peter Parker is already 23 years old, he's seen and beaten some of his (more) famous villains from his rogues gallery, but Insomniac games keeps giving us twists and turns, adding intrigue and mystery, and proves they have more and more to show us. This game is an absolute marvel, in terms of everything; from story-telling and gameplay to it's characters and dialogue. It's *this* close to the perfect Spider-Man game that everyone wanted, but alas, it's not without its flaws. 

It's criticisms lie in some cheesy dialogue bits here and there, the repetitive nature of some of the side-activities, the overall tedium that comes with having to grind to upgrade, and a few other nitpicks. Such as features that some fans wanted but the studio prioritising accessibility and user-friendliness to non-gamers and first-timers, rather than making a more complex system of traversal for experienced and demanding players and blah, blah, blah, puddle-gate (from the original release) and so forth. But really? These are...just nitpicks, I know. 

The only REAL flaw, would be this port sometimes having some weird crashes at inopportune moments, which I feel like harms the entirety of the experience, especially when it's this cinematic - Just imagine watching a movie like this but it freezes and CTDs, like at the strangest moments. It's not crashing frequently... Just randomly. It sometimes runs super well for like 5 hours and then sometimes it just crashes 40 minutes after I launch the game. For one thing, I know it can't be my rig, I got a 3070 Ti and 32Gb of RAM, and I'm running this from my M.2 NVME. But that's just my own experience, it's very much anecdotal, I don't believe others have had this same situation though.

Graphically, this game slaps. It looks and runs amazing, with all it's bells and whistles, ray traced lighting and reflections, all the models and puddles, and character models (I know people complained about the new face, stfu), LOD, particle effects,  and even the shadows, etc. It looked great when I played it on PS4, it looks even better here, like hell, I could just watch the city and the scenery all day. I also really enjoy the real-time graphic changes that you get to see, to be able to examine exactly what the hell you're changing in the graphics options as you are doing it, a very useful feature and tool that should be looked into being implemented in future games, and able to change whether you want it to be more performance or quality oriented and know which setting you want on is absolutely nutty.

Get this game. It's an absolute dream that you won't regret it. At surface-level? You'll at least have fun from the swinging and fighting. Beyond that? Invest in the story and characters. Watch the cutscenes, listen to their dialogue, feel their acting. Play the game, not because you have to, but because you want to. 

SIDE NOTE:
Okay so Spider-Man has always been an fantastic character to me. He was a super-relatable superhero, like when he struggled, we didn't feel like his problems were out of this world, they were something that we could sympathise with. Money problems? I get it. Girl trouble? I feel it. We see the constant struggle of making choices of whether he should do one thing or the other, the responsibility that falls onto his shoulders and the consequences that stemmed from his actions, and we get to put ourselves in his shoes - his mask. The fact was...that he was just the average guy doing his best with the hand that fate had dealt him, and we get to see that through all the spectacular stories that were shown about him. He was, and is, the best superhero. And this game did do him justice. Honestly? This game is one of my favourite media portrayals yet (And I loved Spectacular Spider-Man). Just enjoy the ride. I'm just happy it finally came to PC.

I've played the spider-man and spider-man 2 on a PlayStation 2 and this game is everything I've wished those two to be. Story is rather predictable but good, cutscenes are pretty nice (best part is they are 21:9 and not 16:9), mini-games are really easy but still fun and don't get boring, boss fights are satisfying (regular enemy fights get rather repetitive with 3.5 kinds of enemies game throws at you with different faction models).
Best part of this game is swinging around the beautiful city, which is extremely well done.

Skills (unlike the Miles Morales game) are useful, collecting all the backpacks isn't very grindy and was surprisingly enjoyable due to every single item bringing up some lore. Suits are mostly nice-looking and rarely have useless specials.

Stealth is time-consuming and repetitive but has a rewarding feeling - unlike the Miles Morales game, getting detected just throws you into a fight, so your approach must be very careful.

It runs really smoothly ~150 fps on all high 7900xtx on Linux. Played it with a PS5 controller, which worked great.

This is a great game that makes you really feel like Spider-man, but will frustrate you beyond belief if you are  a capable, skilled gamer. When a game implements AI as this developer has for many of the actions you perform in the game, there will inevitably be instances where the AI makes absolutely the worst decision for you that it can, or it will decide to do something other than what you want to do that you know how to do that you chose to do. 

I don't blame them for this, as this makes the game reachable for more people, I just hate it when a machine makes a bad decision for me or web zips in completely the wrong direction. I can perfect dodge every single attack on the highest difficulty but I'll still be frustrated because the game's AI won't punch the guy I'm aiming for.

As a disclaimer up front, I'm old. I love what this game does with it's story, because mid-twenties Peter Parker is a mess and just starting to pull his adult life together is my jam. From a narrative perspective, this game does so much more to introduce characters and plot points that have been part of Spidey's stories over the decades than anything outside of the first two Raimi movies.

The game has an amazing array of difficulty and accessibility options. It has to be one of the best games I've seen for customizing for exactly what kind of experience you want to  have, within the framework that the developers put together.

Gameplay wise, I will say that the whole section with Scorpion, with swaying landscapes, potential drowning, and hallucinations, was just about too much for me. Not only was it overwhelming for me, but it also felt like shoehorning a Scarecrow Arkham level into a Spider-Man game.

Story wise, there are some missteps. Despite seeing first hand the kind of corruption and biases the police have, Spidey is disconcertingly blind to the possibility that any cop could be less than heroic. I'm not expecting the storyline to focus on police corruption and civil rights, but there are definitely some cringe-worthy hero worshipping moments.

There is also what I think can only be called a thematic fail when it comes to how Spidey and the people in the city refer to the Demons versus the other gangs. Since the group is comprised of Chinese immigrants, it's really uncomfortable when dialogue says things like "Fisk was bad, but he loved this city, but these demons . . . " It really plays into some xenophobic tropes, casting the good old white organized crime boss as being better for New York than these "outsiders." It's not a major theme of the main storyline, but the lines of dialogue get repeated over and over by civilians, cops, and Spidey when he's out and about stopping Demon related crimes.

Narrative and gameplay missteps aside, I loved the story, and I loved the feeling the game gave me. I loved playing with the gadgets, learning how to pull off different moves, and learning enemy weaknesses and tactics. Despite the above flaws, this was an overwhelmingly positive experience for me.

If you have already completed the Batman Arkham series and liked it, then I guess you will probably like Spider-Man also. The characters are not very interesting and the plot is pretty basic.

I personally found Spider-Man to be frustrating at times when it comes to combat and traversal. Spider-Man might just hop onto the trash bags next to him when you wanted to dodge an AOE attack. He might also zip onto a ledge far away when you wanted him to zip on the water tower in front of you. Things like that might not cause a game over and there are ways to mitigate them, but they are frustrating when they cause a challenge to fail.

It's fun to play anyway, especially when traversing through the city and getting into a nice long combo during a fight. The gameplay gets a bit repetitive towards the end, but at least all the boss fights are unique.

Marvel's Spider-Man is one of the best games I have ever played, there are a ton of thing that I enjoyed, It is a beautiful tribute to one of my favorite characters. Insomniac crafted it so well.

Overall the story and city of New York are loyal to the comics and all iterations of Spidey, I loved that they included dozens of cosmetic options for Spidey. Letting you craft you own story to a certain extent.

The DLCs are 100% worth it. They are a great expansion that continues the main story from the game. Contrary to most game DLCs, they do not feel like filler, the characters are expanded upon and transformed in very drastic ways. I even thought at points that The City That Never Sleeps storyline was even better than the main game's story. Silver Sable and Black Cat have become two of my favorite characters. Although I wish to see more of them in a sequel, the Spider-Man universe is so big that I can't wait to see what new heroes and villains Insomniac studios introduces in the future.

A Web-Slinging Adventure!

I wanted to share my excitement about the game "Spider-Man." It's a truly exhilarating journey filled with dynamic gameplay and incredible possibilities.

The standout feature of the game is undoubtedly its gameplay. Swinging through the city on a web is an absolute thrill. You feel free, like a real superhero, and it's just unbelievably cool. The graphics are top-notch, with every corner of New York City meticulously crafted, creating an incredibly realistic world.

However, there's one aspect that left me with mixed feelings - the bosses. In this regard, the game feels slightly underdeveloped. Some boss battles leave something to be desired, and there's a certain repetitiveness in their mechanics. Perhaps the developers could have added more variety to these moments.

Nevertheless, despite this minor drawback, "Spider-Man" is an incredible adventure. The game impresses with its atmosphere, quality of execution, and the capabilities of the main character. If you're a fan of comics or just love great games, then "Spider-Man" is an excellent choice!

Chases are fun, and the interactive cinematic are fun. I have not had any crashes and it runs locked 60fps on my RTX 2060 at 1080p. Visuals very good, and textures load instantly.

EDIT: The one mission where you are MJ sneaking through Sabel camp crashed for me repeatedly, until I turned my resolution down to minimum played through that mission and then reset my settings. I still recommend this game, but if you have a similar card to the RTX 2060 be warned that there are areas that crash consistently, but there is a work around.

This game is for Spiderman what Arkham City was for Batman. I'd argue it's one of the greatest superhero games ever made, but I would not argue it's better than the Arkham games. This game doesn't have quick gadgets, the stealth isn't as good, and the combat isn't as smooth (and dodging is debatably broken). All of that said, it was well worth the time and money put into it - truly a wonderful gaming experience. The storyline is solid, the characters are true to their roots, and you feel like you *are* Peter Parker. The swinging is also fantastic. 9/10 would recommend.

After 100%ing this game I can say I highly suggest this game to anyone. the combat, web swinging, and story are all super fun and really well done. a warning for people trying to 100% the game however: enemies can stun-lock you and if youre on the hardest difficulty (like you have to be for one of the achievements) any spot with more than two snipers can kill you fast but as for the normal difficulty experience: the game is pretty fun and a little challenging although the boss fight at the end of the third DLC is frustratingly difficult even on normal difficulty. The game is fun id check it out if you want one of the best spider-man experiences we've had

Spoiler Free Review:

A strong narrative and game play. This game is something that managed to make both the web swinging and the spider sense feel second nature to utilize but hard to master. This game has potential to be one of the best of the Spider-Man games. Those who are long time fans will be brought back to what  made them fall in love with Spider-Man. The story feels refreshing despite utilizing a familiar cast of characters. If you give this game a chance and go in without the understandable bias of past Spider-Man games this may be in the running for one of your favorite video game iterations of this character. I would recommend 8.5/10.

SPOILER BELOW SPOILER BELOW SPOILER BELOW SPOILER BELOW SPOILER BELOW SPOILER BELOW SPOILER BELOW SPOILER BELOW SPOILER BELOW SPOILER BELOW SPOILER BELOW SPOILER BELOW SPOILER BELOW SPOILER BELOW SPOILER BELOW SPOILER BELOW SPOILER BELOW SPOILER BELOW 

What can be said about this game. It brings an incredible balance between challenge and rewarding game play.  While in games like the Arkham series the counter button can feel hard to justify in the narrative in Spider-Man it fits like a glove with the powers. The incorporation of classic villains is well done but does not stray too far from the main focus and momentum of the story. The cast of villains allows for the world to be fleshed out while supporting the humanity and struggle that our protagonist and supporting good characters go through. While the main story plot lines are predictable in some beats there is still enough emotion and effort in both the writing and the voice actors to convince the audience of the lives being shown to us in this game.

While there is DLC to the game, one dealing with the Black Cat and one dealing with Silver Sabel, I do find these plot lines the lesser when compared to the main story. In all honesty the dlc did not make me feel like what I was doing meaningful to the main story and felt more like switching to filler episodes between the main season plot lines. As of this review I have not played either sequel to this game so I am unsure of the overall connectivity that these dlcs and the main game's story have with the the other games. However, I am left both wanting more and disappointed that it was not able to be delivered in the dlcs.

My only negative about this game, which is something that I have with some of the previous Spider-Man titles, are some of the challenges that you need to complete to get full suit upgrades or 100% the game. Primarily the Screwball challenges, so much hate. None to the voice actress, I am sure she nailed the character but an embarrassing amount of my time on this game was due to some of these challenges.

REVIEW SCORE
9.0/10 - Base Game and Story
8.5/10 - Base Game + DLC Story

I would recommend but if you are going for the 100% some of the challenges require very specific load outs to have a chance. If you get stuck or cannot figure the combos out I would recommend looking it up but your best friend, no matter the difficulty, is your dodge button.

I liked Spider-man cartoons as a kid which is main reason I got this and got a bit of nostalgia hit as it made me feel like I was in a cartoon with all the cheesy lines and Spider man being very faithful to the source material but...

Swinging is the most fun part of the game and still gets boring after around half way point, the combat is extremely basic: button to attack and button to dodge, you can throw in a gadget here and there if you want, but they all do pretty much the same thing. I hate those terrible assassin's creed-like controls, there is exactly zero precision, you press a button and pray the character goes forward. Sidequests aside from very view are generic ubisoft style checkmarks on the map and main missions are just watch a cutscene go place "A" beat up bunch of guys do a qte watch cutscene done. Stealth exists and is more boring than already boring combat. Overall game doesn't deserve overwhelmingly positive rating. Don't even see myself finishing this game. Batman arkham series was way better and this game just made me think about replaying it.

Final point MJ is not hot and the side character missions exist. Who thought when buying Spider-man game I would want to play as anyone other than Spider-man?

Honestly, this is one of the best games I've ever played ngl. The story is exciting as hell, the graphics are extremely beautiful, the game runs very smoothly, the gameplay itself is an absolute joy, the game never crashed a single time and there's plently of stuff to do aside from the story missions. Is there anything more to ask for? I don't think so. 

The swinging from roof to roof, running along building's walls, acquiring various combat techniques made for plently of great action. It actually makes you feel like you are the Spiderman. At the very beginning, learning those skills was quite a challenge, but not for to long fortunately and afterwards it became nearly effortless to jump and swing around the city. 

The combat system is great as well. You never have to be afraid to engage in a fight. Due to the mix of different gadgets and attacks you always feel like it's possible to get the upper hand, even while being outnumbered. Websticking enemies to a wall or a car e.g. is hilarious af.

This game also offers tons of different suits for spiderman, each with its own power and beauty. As soon as you get tired of a particular suit, you can simply just select a new one and before you've done that with each suit, you've already finished this game.

Besides the main story there are also lots of side missions to complete like finding lost backpacks, taking pictures of various landmarks, capturing lots of enemy hideouts, warehouses, outposts as well as prisoners camps, taking down lots of criminals all over the city by preventing their crimes, completing Taskmaster's challenges and so on.

With that being said, I can recommend this game to everyone loving thrilling fun single player games. Not even for a single second I regretted that purchase.

Amazing game, if you've always wanted to play this game on the playstation 4 then I recommend buying it. However, if you're a story-game lover then please try this game out. It's worth every bit of money you spend on it and you won't even regret it.

There are enough reviews exalting the game's strong points, so I might as well get to the bad points. First, the plot and overall narrative got to a point where I just couldn't empathize with Spider-Man anymore. The way he was written in this game makes it so that he has a very specific moral compass, and he feels the need to constantly impose it on all of those around him. “You are not like this” or “I can’t let you do that” are perhaps the phrases most employed by him during the game, and it becomes annoying as hell. Writing is not the game’s strong point, and there is quite a bit of it.

Second, the Mary Jane missions are really as uninteresting as other have to you they are; it’s a chore to go through all but one of them, which is ironically the one in which she actually partners with Spider-Man in gameplay terms. Third, the quality of the DLC felt perceptively lower to me in most aspects, and they bring just about nothing new to the game other than tougher enemies... maybe unnecessarily tough, at that. In hindsight, I maybe wouldn’t have played the DLC if I knew how stale they were. To me, the most enjoyable parts were the Screwball challenges, which added actual new ideas that felt fun to accomplish.

So, should you play this game? Well, it’s definitely not a necessity like almost everyone seems to imply. Play it if it feels attractive to you, and maybe skip the DLC.

If you are a fan of Spider-Man, Marvel, or superheroes in general, you will love this game.

As I write this, I have just finished the main story. But don't worry - I'll keep this as spoiler-free as possible! I have not yet tackled the DLC or 100% completed the game or anything like that, but I loved the entire experience enough that yes, I probably will go the extra mile to do ALL the things.

I don't know much about the team that put this game together, but it definitely FEELS like a passion project, lovingly crafted by a bunch of hardcore Spidey enthusiasts. Whatever your favorite version/portrayal of Spider-Man is, whatever your favorite THING about Spider-Man is, it's represented here. It hits all the right emotional beats, and it's seriously impressive how the action sequences feel like big blockbuster films. There are some villains I'm really looking forward to seeing in this universe that haven't shown up yet, but the ones we DO get are very dynamic and interesting, and the boss fights against them are so much fun and everything I would've hoped for in a video game fight against them. The final boss fight in particular is PERFECTION, as well as a certain team-up boss fight at the end of Act 2.

Spider-Man does have a very similar feel to the Batman: Arkham games. The combat systems are similar in how they're controlled, but I found Spidey's acrobatic flips and jumps way more entertaining and thrilling to watch. Like the Arkham games, there are a lot of stealth sections where you're required to take enemies out one at a time without being seen, and that did feel a bit out of place to me - it's on brand for Batman, but doesn't quite fit the colorful, flashy, wise-cracking style of Spidey. There are also segments where you play as different characters in more stealthy, information-gathering types of missions, and I found them to be a fun break from the action.

And then there's the web-slinging. Woooooooowwwwwwee swinging around the city is SO fun!!! It never gets old. There is a fast travel option, but I found myself rarely using it. Even walking around at street level gets interesting, as people have a variety of different ways they respond to you. Some of them yell conspiracy theories out at you and call you a menace, some come up and high-five you. There is a LOT of life and personality in every aspect of this game. The version of New York City you're in is also very interesting - it's got a blend of real-life streets and buildings, and ones from Marvel's lore. Avengers Tower, the Chrysler building, the Wakanda Embassy, the Empire State Building... I even went out of my way to look for the Osborn penthouse and the Daily Bugle building from Raimi's Spider-Man trilogy, because they're real buildings in New York City (and yes, I found them!).

I still intend to play the DLC and do some of the extra collecting, but I already have the sequel, Spider-Man: Miles Morales, and am looking forward to playing it! Here's hoping Spider-Man 2 comes out on Steam soon as well for those of us that don't have a PS5. I love this game and I am definitely hooked!! If you're a fan of Spider-Man, I'm sure there is a lot to love here for you as well!

Wow! I spent possibly 3 out of 4h played just swinging through Manhattan. It's insane how accurate the city looks. I was able to just visit certain landmarks like the Bull of Wall Street or the Radio City building from memory. Recognised the place I had a beer with a mate five years ago, a proper trip through memory lane.

The mechanics are so great. It took a bit to get used to but after an hour I was gracefully flying across the Village up towards the Financial District. Combat is really acrobatic as well, and although this likewise takes some getting used to, once you grasp the mechanics and start learning the moves of the enemies you'll start chaining combos with ease. The main missions are engaging, with some fun changes where you play MJ or a character called Miles. The story is top-notch introducing some noteworthy Villains into the mix, starting out strong with an excellent opening mission and building up speed gradually during it's runtime before finishing off even stronger in one of the best final acts I've seen in a video game. The quality writing is also found in the often humorous dialogue and the outright hilarious podcast fragments from J Jonah Jameson, former editor of the Daily Bugle.

There's plenty of side content, and I did it all because it didn't feel tedious. Sure it has collectables in the form of backpacks hidden on skyscrapers or underneath bridges, and you're supposed to sneak a pic of some of this Marvelised Manhattan's famous landmarks, but because the gameplay, and especially the zipping around the city is so much fun, these collectables are just things you pick up over the course of the game. Or the first Act, in my case. There's several side missions, and a number of enemy bases that add additional gameplay into the mix, and during the campaign there is random street crime popping up all around you allowing you to climb into the role of that Friendly Neighbourhood Spider-Man we all know and love.

All in all the main campaign and 100% completion of the map (but without nailing gold on all challenges) took me 35 hours, with plenty of time spend just swinging around. There's also DLC included which adds about another 12 hours to the game. Although not as good as the main game, it's still excellent with some really fun missions. The dynamic between Black Cat and Spider-Man in the first DLC is particularly great. Finally there's a NG+, though after 47+ hours of swinging around Manhattan, I'm gonna give that a rest for now.

Sony got bingo:
God of war - crap
Horizon - crap
Spider-Man - crap
I am sort of amazed how they waste such potential and scale. And also by the fact that people bought consoles to play those.

The only fun thing is web slinging and going through city (and it takes some time to get used to it).
Controls are unresponsive - you shoot web or kick after about half second. And It actually gets you in trouble sometimes when you do chasing missions. And more often when you fight: you do wrong moves on wrong targets and so on.
Obligatory, totally boring grind such as getting tons of backpacks, doing photos, doing boring researches. All felt like chore and not fun at all.
Fisk building sites - literally outposts from Far Cry.
Why lock roaming movements as skills? It should be available as default so you can fiddle with it while going through city.
Uninspiring stealth, uninspiring boss fights with zero flexibility and i almost didn't get into the story.
Dead and empty so-called open world.
Chasing missions are exhausting.
Lab researches with circuits are not challenging and are complete waste of time. In Bioshock you could buy out or use autohack when you really don't want to put pipes manually.
At least graphics look pretty nice.

Гринд-обязаловка: собери рюкзаки, пофотай местность, поделай исследования. Все это тупо ощущалось какой-то рутиной и просто не радовала.

97/100 Masterpiece

[h2] My Experience [/h2]
This was one of the best gaming experiences I have ever had, this is the best open-world game I have ever played since
[u] TLOZ: Breath of The Wild [/u] in 2019 and the UI looks almost as good if not better. The character designs look good, there are many different things you can do, the game feels emotional but intense at the same time.

[h2] Controls [/h2]
So the controls are really good, even if they feel a little clunky sometimes there still isn't really anything to criticize about.
The swinging feels good, it's super satisfying and easy to learn.

[h2] Gameplay [/h2]
SPOILER ALERT:
Let's get straight to the point, the gameplay is SUPER GOOD. But sometimes it just feels too Intense when you have 30 Demons and 15 Sable Agents on your ass. (Yes I'm talking about the moments before the last Mr. Negative fight) 
Of course you can change the difficulty, but I personally like playing games the way they are supposed to be played. 
But anyway the fighting feels good, the movement looks fresh and the gameplay is not too difficult at all. Now there is a slight stealth aspect to the game and I know some people wont like that but it's not too bad.

[h2] Graphics [/h2]
The graphics in this game are amazing, and I don't even have an RTX graphics card so I can't use ray-tracing (I have a GTX 1660 Super). 
The game never even really lagged for me either, the character designs look fresh (As I mentioned before), 
All the buildings look nice, trees look good and I don't really know what else to say.

[h2] The Story [/h2]
BIG SPOILER WARNING:
The story in this game feels intense, emotional, sad, and heartwarming all at the same time. The start of the game when Peter almost gets evicted as always is nothing special really, but after that when Fisk get defeated, Fisk Tower gets blown up from the inside and you get introduced to the Demons, the game really starts. GR-27 is still a mystery and you're trying to find out what it is. The city hall bombing happens and you find out that it has something to do with the Demons.
Then you sneak into the Oscorp Tower and invade the government database infrastructures, it feels like a whole movie. 
Now i wont spoil anything anymore but I'm sure that every single person who likes the Spider-Man Movies will like this game.

[h2] More Information [/h2]
I haven't completed this game 100% yet, but i have completed the main story. And my older brother has 233 hours on this game and he loved every single bit of it, he did play the DLCs and has 100% on this game but i would think that like 60$ is pretty cheap for 233 hours of fun and enjoyment i have like 200 hours on [u] TLOZ: Breath of The Wild [/u] and that game is 60$ but i have 100% completed it like 5 times so i would say 60$ for this game is a pretty good deal

Having completed the main story line (84% complete), I do agree that the game is great. My only real issue with the game is the bugs, it's much more buggy than I was expecting. There were minor ones (enemies catching on geometry) to backpacks not loading in to interactive objectives not being clickable (both of which necessitated restarts) to crashes. The worst issue though is the bug where failing the stealth side objectives and resetting it caused the game to crash. I couldn't then restart the game to the last save point, the only reason I didn't lose all my progress to a game breaking bug is because I did manual saves as well. Based on some quick research, this bug has been around for years, I don't know why a game breaking bug like this is still there. Still, it's a great game regardless of the bugs

I finally finished the main story last night, thanks in part to the release of the sequel. I want to play it but not before finishing this one, and I didn’t want to wait 2 years for it to come to PC. Some console games really require you to accept low fidelity or bad performance (and it’s not uncommon to experience both), but the one exception to this issue is games from PlayStation Studios like Insomniac, who are technically experienced and know how to ship a beautiful, performant game on the PS5 hardware. I have no doubt that Nixxes will release a superior version on PC, just like they did here with the first game, but I just didn’t want to wait. 

This Spider-Man remastered is the PC version of the PS5 game that featured upgrades like ray traced reflections, UW support, support for upscaling tech (DLSS/FSR 2/XeSS/and Insomniac’s own Temporal upscaler), and DLSS Frame Generation feature for RTX 4000 cards is also present in this game. The game is a showcase of Nixxes’ ability to port games to PC at a higher quality level than pretty much anyone else. They are just so awesome, I love them and feel that they are a beacon of hope in the current era of PC gaming which is experiencing dark times in 2023. It’s ironic that they are owned by PlayStation, but as long as PC players benefit, it doesn’t really matter. 

The game itself is a very fun Spider-Man, open world game with a focus on the narrative. It took me almost 40 hours to complete this and I didn’t complete all of the side content or the DLCs yet. This is why I don’t trust HLTB’s estimates, people play through games at different speeds. It’s not like I spent 10 hours webbing up and down the streets of manhattan doing nothing, 80% of my time was focused on the main storyline and the the other 20% was spent doing side content like complete base challenges and collecting backpacks. I could have done it a little faster maybe, but not in 17.5 hours (HLTB’s estimate).

If you are a fan of Marvel comics/TV/films (I don’t blame you if you’re not), then you should enjoy this game. The Marvel that I grew up with in the 90s animated shows and comics as a kid is somewhat different than the heavily, heavily commercialized Disney version of Marvel in 2023. It turns me off to a lot of Marvel stuff nowadays, I feel that a lot of the original stories have been somewhat undermined and lessened in value because of Disney’s need to maximize profits making an unlimited number of TV shows, films, video games, merchandise, etc etc. This is relevant because despite me feeling this way about modern day Marvel, I still enjoyed this game and had a fun time with it. I think it’s worth full price if you want to buy it immediately, but the smarter move is to wait for a sale, Sony always discounts their games for the big Steam seasonal sales.

I can't speak for the original version of this Spider-Man, I've only played the remaster.

I really enjoyed this iteration of Spider-Man. It's a classic remaster of what a lot of people, me included, loved on the PS2, too bad we didn't get that classic pizza delivery theme. I like the newer actor's face capture, it feels more "friendly neighborhood Spider-Man," the original just doesn't seem right to me.

The combat is great, it's the Arkham gameplay with combos and finishers and flows great, very fluid, especially after unlocking a decent portion of the skill tree, which doesn't take too long. The finisher animations are great as well, except for that one wrestling finisher with the unnecessary double slow-mo....

The world and story go pretty good together. It's a pretty solid chunk of time just to get through the main story, and they jam-pack a LOT into every nook and cranny of the world. Manhattan's split up into about 8 sections, each of which has collectibles, side quests, and oh-so-many crimes to stop (seriously, I could've 100% the game about 2hrs sooner if there weren't so many damn crimes, and in the DLCs too!). The traversal mechanics are great, and really make you feel like Spider-Man, though they do get just a touch stale after maybe halfway through the game, where you can almost predict each motion Spidey's gonna make, a bit of variety would've been nice here, and the Miles Morales sequel does this much better.

The characters are cast perfect for their roles, Doc Oc feels like Doc Oc, MJ feels like MJ, and Pete definitely feels like a Spider-Man. The lab missions almost feel like a side-bit to the story, not relevant to stopping the main villain, as you watch Octavius' slowly spiral into madness, until suddenly he's not such a side character anymore, which is done really well, and the Act II finale really pulls you in and starts to feel much more serious than the first arc of the game.

The DLCs are pretty well done, very short but I think that's fine considering there's three of them. As for map content, I think they went a bit overboard with all the forts/hideouts. Fisk, Demons, Sable, Prisoners, one of each in every district started to feel like homework when it came to cleaning up the map, and similar to the movement I think Miles Morales' sequel did this much better.

Overall it's a solid implementation of what most people expect for the classic Spider-Man experience, if you enjoyed any of the Tobey Maguire movies as a kid you'll love this.

Still working my way through the DLC, but Spider-Man has been a great experience. Strong recommend even if you're like me and not someone who's super into superhero stuff and Spider-Man specifically. Combat is fun, web swinging is amazing, the open world is large enough to really enjoy exploring around, and small enough to feel like it's "completable" unlike some open world games these days (hem hem, Ubisoft). 

I appreciate that the game skips the origin story we've all seen a million times and takes you straight into the meat. It builds slowly but then you get some really great character moments both with Peter & MJ, but also between Peter and his enemies and new friends along the way. Really enjoyable. I do wish the side activities (specifically the labs and crimes) were a bit less repetitive, but that's fine. It's also fun to have so many Spidey suits to unlock and choose from.

I have some mixed notes about performance. On the one hand, it performs AMAZINGLY. I get 100 fps + the vast majority of the time on my 3070ti + i5-13600k, with everything set to ultra. I did eventually have to drop Ray Tracing and a couple other settings because I was getting severe frame drops after playing the game for more than 30-60 minutes. It's reminiscent of a memory leak issue where the longer you play, the worse the performance gets, but dropping RT helped tremendously. 

However, my big gripe with performance is the crashing. This game crashes A LOT. Most of the time, it's on loading screens, but every once in a while while playing as well (usually when swinging around for me). It's extremely frustrating, because the save also "breaks" and you can't load it again without either validating the files, or in my case, loading in on my Steam deck, progressing a little to a new save, then reloading on my PC. This happens way, way too often, and has often left me feeling negatively towards the game after a solid enjoyable session just ends and I can't continue without jumping through hoops. I've taken to keeping three separate manual saves to make sure I don't lose too much progress when it happens. 

Overall, I'd give it a strong recommendation with the caveat that the frequent crashes detract a lot from the experience, so make sure you have the patience to deal with that.

So I have over a hundred hours in both this and Miles on the PS4/5 combined, have 100% completion on both multiple times just to preface this. 

Absolutely one of the best games to come out in the last decade. Insomniac revived a franchise that hadn't had a great game since the ps2 days and they absolutely smashed it. From story to gameplay this game is just *fun*. I never use fast travel because swinging around is just so [u]fun[/u]. I never get tired of the combat because it's just [u]fun[/u]. 

Whether you're a hyper critical player or a chilled out lil goofy guy playin' games, I can honestly recommend it to everyone.

The only cons I have, and these seem extremely PC specific, are that the physics on some things (ragdolls, objects after you throw them and they hit something) seem to depend on your framerate, and because mine is quite high (100+ at all times) it looks goofy as hell. This wasn't and still isn't a thing on the playstation. The rest of the physics in the game work just fine, though. 

Secondarily, and it's been a while since I played through the full story on Playstation, but there were WAY more visual glitches in this. They tended to be cases where an object from the game world stayed loaded in to a cutscene, so a person just phased through a car, or had a mailbox blocking them and such.

The last is something that I [u]know[/u] for a fact is PC specific, and it does not matter which controller you use. There seems to be a bug where finishers/suit powers, basically anything requiring 2 inputs will stop working. Sometimes even the gadget button. This seems to be related to scene changes like cutscene to gameplay or vice versa but sometimes it just clocks out. As I mentioned above, I have completed the game many times on PS4/5 and not once had as much trouble as I do with this sometimes. It could also be tied to framerate. This usually isn't too big an issue but the challenges in the game it's a nightmare.

Other than that, it worked flawlessly and played like the game I fell in love with in 2018.

Good Spider-Man game, visually stunning, featuring enjoyable, smooth, and innovative combat and movement systems. The only drawback lies in the limited mission variety; the repetitive tasks in different scenarios can feel a bit redundant. Nonetheless, I highly recommend this game for beginners seeking a stress-free and relaxing gaming experience.

[h1]Spider-Man Remastered is a very good superhero game. I'm a big fan of the Batman Arkham series, and this game is very similar to that.[/h1]

[b]Insomniac Games has really managed to capture the feeling of being like Spider-Man. It's a lot of fun swinging around the city fighting criminals. Towards the end, however, some activities feels a bit repetitive.[/b]

[h3]Story & Characters.[/h3]
The story is good and interesting and really feels like a typical Spider-Man story. However, it is quite predictable. All of the most famous characters are there, like MJ, Aunt May, the Osborns, etc. Miles Morales is also introduced, and fits well into the story. They really nailed Peter Parker. He is funny and a bit insecure, as he should be. The game also has humor, which made me laugh more than once.

[h3]The World & Graphics.[/h3]
The city of New York is very beautiful, and I can't really complain about the graphics. The city feels very free and alive, whether you are running on the streets, jumping over rooftops, or swinging between buildings. People on the street talk to you and adore you, giving you a high five sometimes. If you stand in the middle of the street, the cars will honk their horn, wanting you to move out of the way. Birds on the rooftops fly away as you come running and jumping. And more. You can swing with your webs from anything you can imagine that you can swing from, such as buildings, trees, lampposts, etc. The swinging is very fun, and even though there is a fast travel system, I found myself swinging across NYC instead. So well done, Insomniac.

[h3]Missions, Challenges, & Activities.[/h3]
There are only a few side quests to do, but regardless of main quest or side quest, the quests are varied and it doesn't feel like you're doing the same thing more than once. There are also lots of different activities to do, like collectibles to find, enemy bases to conquer, some Taskmaster challenges to tackle, and more. Some of the activities become quite repetitive after a while, such as stopping random encounters with criminal gangs in the city. All challenges, activities and collectibles are clearly marked on the map, and emit a large beam into the air so they are easy to find. Very nice and easy to get 100% on this game without having to check a guide! 

So about the Taskmaster Challenges. There are 4 different challenges in the game; Combat, Stealth, Bombs, and Drones. The one most important criterion on which you’re judged in Taskmaster Challenges is speed. Whether you’re beating down enemies, stealthing through a hideout, chasing drones, or defusing bombs, it’s all about how fast you can finish the task. In the Batman games, there were certain objectives you HAD to master to get the highest score. In this game it doesn't really matter how you complete the challenge, it doesn't really matter if you get hit many times in a combat challenge and so on, as long as you complete the challenge fast enough. This was a bit disappointing in my opinion. The drone challenges were the most annoying in my opinion. All of these different challenges are not as fun as in the Arkham games, and they are also much easier. The DLC also adds some new challenges, the Screwball challenges, and those were really annoying. It was all about photobombing, and I hated that.

[h3]Enemies & Bosses.[/h3]
There is a decent variety of enemies in the game, and some have to be defeated in a certain way. Some enemies, for example, have shields or electric batons and you can't just hit them straight ahead, just like in the Batman games.

You get to meet many famous bosses during the game which was fun, like Electro, Doctor Octopus, Vulture etc. The only thing that I found a bit annoying about the bosses was that the bosses do not have a visible health bar. I like to see how much damage I do and how much HP a boss has left.

[h3]The Combat.[/h3]
The combat is very similar to the Batman Arkham games. On the other hand, I think that the Batman games were more fun when it comes to this part. I wouldn't say it's necessarily "better" combat in Batman, but it's a little different. If you try to play as Batman in this game, you will get beat. You can't just stand your ground like Batman can. You have to think more like Spider-Man, jump around a lot, use your gadgets often, etc.

The combat in this game is more "chaotic". There are too many things happening at once sometimes, like rockets coming at you from rocket launchers while a shielded enemy charges you and leaves an AOE DOT on the ground as well, so even if you dodge the rocket and the charge, you might land in that AOE DOT anyway. In this game, you can't make a counter attack in the same way as in the Batman games. In this game, when the counter icon appears above the head, you have to dodge instead, and if you time it perfectly you will also shoot web back at that enemy, making them open for an instant takedown.

I think that both Batman himself and the combat system have more variety in the Arkham games. Both when it comes to how you build the combos and the variety of animations and takedowns. Spider-Man does more or less the same thing, shooting webs or kicks, and it looks very much the same all the time.

In the Batman games freeflow combat system, you could press the attack button when you were as far as maybe 15-20 meters away from the enemy, and Batman would close the gap on that enemy and punch that enemy. You did not have to run over to the enemy you wanted to hit, you only had to press the attack button and Batman "flew" over there, without losing the combo. This was very smooth, and it is not the case in this game. In this game, it only works up to maybe 2 meters. Otherwise Spider-Man just stands there and kicks in the air, which was a bit annoying at first. You don't lose the combo from this, but still. You just have to remember to use your web instead to close the gap on the enemy. All of this may just be a matter of preference and getting used to, but in that case I prefer the Batman Arkham style combat more.

[h3]Crashing.[/h3]
I don't know why, but this game crashed very often for me, and it made me very frustrated at times. I tried many different graphics settings, even turned some of them off, but it didn't help. It seems many others have had similar problems. This happened mostly during the challenges in the game. I played a challenge, and every time I failed it or wanted to restart it, the game crashed. It ruins the experience a bit, having to restart the game all the time. During my 47 hours of playtime, the game must have crashed at least 30 times, no joke. I don't have old computer parts either.

[h1]The Verdict.[/h1]
If you are looking for a superhero game that makes you feel like the superhero yourself in an open world, and is similar to the Batman Arkham games, then I highly recommend that you try this out. 4/5.

its very fun
Great game !

So, I basically had a blast spending thirty minutes enjoying the photo mode, observing the plasticity of Black Cat...

Graphically, the game looks fantastic! Especially at 165 frames per second and with the settings cranked up to the maximum.

The storyline of the game is wonderful and interesting. I've always loved Spider-Man as a hero, and, in my opinion, the development studio brought him to life in a very interesting and solid way. Cutscenes are superb, the direction is mind-blowing, and the actors play vividly. Spider-Man cracks jokes and makes comments. All of this brought me delight.

But, oh gods, the developers stretched the game in the most disgusting way for me by stuffing it with a huge pile of repetitive activities! I would have been completely satisfied with this game if it could be completed in about twenty to twenty-five hours.

Maybe, again, it's my problem that I decided to play it all at once. But when each DLC offered me to clear bases and solve crimes again, I honestly howled!

The technical state is also strange. In the second act, when fast-travel [i](and during loading)[/i] in the northern part of the city, the game simply crashed for me. I fixed this by changing the resolution and reducing all the settings, but in the third act, the issue resolved itself. But I remembered the good old times when you had to save manually and almost resort to save-scumming.

They give you a piece of the plot, and then you fly around the whole map for damn two hours clearing "outposts." Outposts, while entertaining with Peter's commentary, made me just turn on YouTube and start zoning out. Between some missions, the hero suggests closing activities in the city [i](in the DLC, it seems to happen after every mission, even though the DLCs are very short)[/i]. But they generously load you with content: crimes of criminals, crimes of saboteurs, crimes of cuckoldry, paintings, backpacks [i](backpacks are okay, actually)[/i], audio diaries, hidden photo places, bases, prison bases, sledgehammer bases, sables bases . By the twenty-fifth hour of gameplay, I was honestly tired [i](how I squirted when in the third act they again suggested clearing the city)[/i]. In the end, I tried to skip as many skirmishes as possible, as I had reached the maximum level and just didn't want to engage in yet another monotonous battle.

I probably didn't mention stealth; well, I'm not lazy, why is it even needed here? Thanks for making it passable enough.

Progression was both sufficient and insufficient for me simultaneously. But starting from the DLC, there was nowhere to put the experience, and it would have been nice to add some possibilities.

The DLCs are very short in terms of the story [i](even considering that there are missions with escort and eavesdropping, we still love them, right?)[/i], and they stuffed the same formula of additional activities as in the main game to vacuum the city once again.

Mixed feelings about the game. I can't say the game is bad, but I'm tired of it. Thumbs up because the game was purchased [b]on sale[/b], and the story is genuinely enjoyable.

I think this game is kind of objectively good, but it has issues like story elements that don't come together super well or things that subjectively frustrate me like the suit system being composed of referential suits as opposed to original designs or something where the default suit changes appearance as you upgrade.
the combat just isn't as sharp as something like arkham either; there were so many times where I'd get locked into an animation and be unable to do anything about a grenade or times when a rocket comes at me from off screen without warning  

if I had to single out a particular issue that kind of made me regret playing this though, it'd be the copoganda
I knew it was going to be a thing going in, but I had no idea that it was going to be egregious as it was.
where that sort of thing can make sense with more neo-liberal characters like batman, it just makes no sense here

"Marvel's Spider-Man Remastered" is not just a visual overhaul of the acclaimed 2018 title; it's an essential play for both newcomers and veterans alike. This remaster enhances what was already considered one of the best superhero games to date, making it an even more compelling experience.

The narrative remains one of the game's strongest suits. It tells an original story that is not tied to any existing comic book or film, giving the developers at Insomniac Games the freedom to explore mature themes and craft a narrative that is both respectful of the source material and fresh. Peter Parker is portrayed with a depth that captures his dual life as a young adult grappling with personal challenges and his heroic alter-ego Spider-Man. The story is replete with emotional beats, well-placed humor, and a portrayal of iconic characters that feel three-dimensional and real.

Visually, the remaster is a triumph. It's not simply a higher resolution pass but a comprehensive upgrade. Improved textures, better lighting with ray tracing capabilities, and enhanced character models bring New York City to life with astonishing detail. The remaster takes full advantage of the hardware capabilities of the PlayStation 5, delivering not only a more beautiful rendition of the game but also one that benefits from reduced loading times and smoother performance.

Gameplay in "Spider-Man Remastered" remains as fluid and engaging as ever, with the remaster enhancing the experience with more stable frame rates and responsive controls. Swinging through the city is an unparalleled joy, with an intuitive system that makes traversal an integral part of the game's appeal. Combat is dynamic and encourages creativity, allowing players to combine Spider-Man's acrobatic skills and gadgets in exhilarating ways.

The sound design and musical score are also noteworthy, with the remaster ensuring that audio fidelity is top-notch. The orchestral score dynamically changes with the action, and the environmental sounds of the city add a layer of immersion that is crucial for a game that thrives on its setting.

One significant change in the remaster is the new face model for Peter Parker. While initially a point of contention among fans, this change brings Peter's appearance more in line with the voice actor's facial structure, enhancing the performance capture and emotional expressions in the game.

In terms of content, "Spider-Man Remastered" includes not just the base game but also all three chapters of the "The City That Never Sleeps" DLC, providing even more narrative content and gameplay. This makes the remastered edition the definitive version of the game, offering the complete experience in one package.

The game also offers accessibility features, making it more inclusive to a broader range of players. These include options for subtitle customization, different control schemes, and visual aids, ensuring that as many players as possible can enjoy the game.

In conclusion, "Marvel's Spider-Man Remastered" refines and enhances an already exceptional game. It's an ode to the beloved character of Spider-Man, a technical marvel that pushes the boundaries of the hardware, and a narrative adventure that tugs at the heartstrings while providing adrenaline-pumping action. For its captivating story, exhilarating gameplay, and stunning visual presentation, "Spider-Man Remastered" is a must-play for anyone with the opportunity to experience it on the PlayStation 5 and PC

I haven't played any Spider-Man related games since Spider Man 2 game from 2004. So being able to swing through new york as my childhood's favourite superhero brought back many memories and nostalgia. The game may not pose any great challenge, but it is pleasant in its simplicity. The greatest advantage of the insomniac studio's production is its stunning graphics, which bring a cinematic experience during cutscenes. Side activities in the open world of Marvel's Manhattan are simple, but the most fun for me was just swinging around the city. Patrolling New York City looking for villains is truly immersive. Without beating around the bush, the game is worth recommending, but it is worth waiting for a discount because the price of $60 may not suit everyone for a game with about 40 hours of gameplay including expansions.

Good thing that Rhino is cooler than back in 2004 and I'm finally able to beat him tho, although the old one was much more creepy.

This is an excellent super hero video game.

I honestly don't think I can say much about the game beyond that, which other people haven't already addressed, but I'll add my voice to the many others recommending this game.

If you've ever wanted to play a Spider-Man game that gave you the perfect Spider-Man experience, swinging around the skyscrapers of Manhattan, New York City, beating up bad guys, defeating super villains, helping local residents, and also playing Peter Parker when the time calls for it, look no further than this game. It perfectly encapsulates that experience, with a little "hi-tech flair" added to the mix.

Also, this isn't the Tobey Maguire Spider-Man, or Andrew Garfield Spider-Man, or even your Tom Holland Spider-Man, this is a new Spider-Man entirely, with his own version of the story, and his own conclusion, his own villains, and so on. The game contains a lot of extra Spider-Man suits that can make him *look* like those other Spider-Men, but that's mostly just a neat bit of fanservice for the really hardcore Spider-Man fans.

Marvel's Spider-Man is an open-world game, so of course it comes with the usual trappings of an open world game like collectible items, photo challenges, mini-games, side-quests and radio towers, so if you're not a fan of that, be warned. That being said, it's not as bad as stuff like the Assassin's Creed games, where there's more than 200 feathers scattered across multiple cities, and they're functionally worthless. Here they serve a purpose in the form of upgrading resources for your equipment.

This Remastered Edition comes with all the DLC attached, so there's nothing extra you have to buy, not even cosmetics. Everything must be earned in-game, so if there's a specific suit you've been eyeing, you can't just pull out your wallet for it, which is refreshing. You get the entire game with a one-time purchase, something you kinda miss these days. (Looking at you, Ubisoft).

Best Spider-Man game on the PC hands down. The writing, especially Spideys, is excellent, the VAs do a splendid job at portraying their respective characters, there's so much to do and so much room to do it in, combat is a spectacle, just challenging enough, and as varied as you want it to be, music is catchy and fitting, and the web-swinging is genuinely the most enjoyable traversal in a game like this that I experienced. It does Spidey justice in so, so many ways.
I think the two points I can bring up as negative - enemies seriously dogpiling you and fast chase scenes losing momentum when you slam into a tiny corner of a building - can't even really be chalked up as negatives; if you're more skilled at this than me, you won't have problems with either.

If you're a fan of Spider-Man, this is an absolute must-have.

Original: It's pretty good! You have enough variation that every time you play the game it feels different. Unlike other games, taking photos and collecting backpacks are a breeze and refreshing between main missions. Sometimes you can play in the perspective of another character which allows you to get to know characters in a more personal way. Overall, I could put countless hours into this game.

Extensive: Now that I've played 25 hours+ hours, I can give a solid review. Well, it's Spider-Man, Do you want to fight crimes? Do you want to be a hero or menace? Do you want something to do in your spare time? It covers all of this. Never in my life have I avoided a fast travel system so quickly after it was introduced. It's unnecessary unless you only have time for short play sessions, just traverse the map as intended. The story was decent and the more you progressed, the more it got tougher. If you are new to this game, I'd recommend playing on the Friendly Neighborhood (Very Easy) or Friendly (Easy), this is due to me playing normal and still being beaten uncontrollably. If you want a challenge then go for Amazing (Normal), Spectacular (Hard), or Ultimate (Very Hard). Various villains were great to see and they all had equal on-screen time which blew me away. I highly recommend playing the DLC as it expands upon the story and adds many side missions which allows you more tokens to unlock suits, skills, etc. Plus if you are planning to play Marvel's Spider-Man: Miles Morales, it's best to work towards that story-wise.

i'd give this game a solid 8/10, strong compelling story telling is where this game really shines, the characters were will written and the villains were very interesting, the combat in the game is fun but its also very easy to cheese encounters and make it a cake walk XD, the amount of times you can use spider bro at the beginning of a fight and basically do nothing is extremely funny, however it doesn't mean the combat is bad, its pretty good in fact especially when you combo gadget attacks and are kicking people in the air, its quite fun! the traversal is absolutely fantastic in this game and i can't remember using fast travel at all during my first play time, it was just to much fun. the suits are amazing and so is the sound track, the only thing holding this game back is competitive side missions, yeah i'm sick of stopping a car now XD and some slow missions in the story with miles and mj, there should have been less of those, the screwball challenges were more annoying than anything is tbh  and the dlc well fun i wasn't sold on the main villain and some of the plot, just give us more black cat! i also wish we had more time fighting the main villains aswell, like the amount of times we fought shocker should have been for everyone, but this is still such a fantastic game and i highly recommend it.

This game is an absolute masterpiece and such an evolution of Spider-Man games as a whole, the swinging feels incredible and the combat is great too. The story is what I think shines the most though, having kept me invested until the very end, and keeping me going even though the game had already exhausted me with all the side activities that were quite frankly way too much and kinda bloated the game a bit. This is my favorite Peter Parker story, and it's refreshing that they didn't include an origin story for him, and instead focus on a more experienced Parker and the origin stories of Doctor Octopus and the Brooklyn Spider-Man. The game also made me cry at the end of the main campaign. All around great experience.

This game is *amazing*.
The story is incredible. Every part of it is entertaining, and when you think it's going to get boring, it gets better. It is exciting in all of the best ways. Even the side missions are fun.
The gameplay is very engaging. The combat is definitely repetitive, but it still manages to feel fun every time. The puzzles/minigames are a bit bland, but I would encourage you to do them anyways.
However, one major flaw with the game is how often it crashes. Every so often, the game will just crash. This seems to be an experience many people are having. It's not a gamebreaking issue, but it's definitely annoying. 
Overall, I would recommend this game. Its many upsides outweigh its downsides. You won't regret buying it.

The combat has just enough variety to be addicting and the web swinging is pure joy, but this game is carried by its story. This is eight years after Peter became Spider-Man, but there are optional missions, dialogue, and collectibles for anyone interested in backstory. Meanwhile the in-game plot is phenomenal! All you need to know is that this is NOT a "bad guy is just evil so beat him up" story. All major problems are eventually explained, and I got emotionally invested enough to tear up at the end.

[b]This game is absolutely worth your money, just make sure that your PC is powerful enough to run it.[/b] This ain't the type of game you can play on your calculator.

When swinging around as Spider-Man, it gives me that feeling of being in the theater back in 2002, watching Spider-Man swing around those buildings and fighting crime around New York City. Especially since it gives you the option to use a suit FROM that series of movies(!!) and from other iterations of Spider-Man over the years.

I can't stress it enough, it's just FUN. I load into the game, I can instantly just find myself swinging aimlessly for hours on end (literally) and just BEING Spider-Man.

The only thing I would want in this game that isn't already there, more mention and (direct) involvement of other Marvel characters, heroes and villains.

Overall I'd say 11/10, this is what superhero-type games SHOULD be, just pure fun and giddy.

It's good, it's fun, but …

It's not Batman Arkham, despite what people say. The controls (PC) are awkward, especially during quicktime events where you actually have to look at the keyboard. I'm still fighting getting to all the keys after most of the main story. The collectibles are nice and fun, but seriously, Spidy catching pidgeons made me lose it, it just feels forced. I get they want to make it like Gotham, just bigger and more and better. I just don't get why they don't use the huge rooster of Marvel villains to put up more interesting side missions, but let us photograph landmarks (repeated later with plushy cats) and catch pidgeons.

Don't get me wrong, it's certainly an AAA game, and it's fun, I like it, and I'll play the sequels. But it's not Batman Arkham.

(Maybe the sequels are. I remember having quite some "buts" after playing Arkham Asylum first. But Arkham City is close to unbeatable.)

I didn't give Spider-man series the chance early, because i wasn't confident i would enjoy a super hero game, but i was surprisingly hooked by it!
I am a marvel fan since childhood, especially spider-man is one of the heroes i was reading comics with.

The game is just amazing! It has a well written story line, amazing narrative, and the combat and web-slinging mechanics will make it feel like you want to lose hours just exploring the city.

I really have to address the fact that i had a major bug in the second episode of the DLC, the Turf Wars. My game just crashes every time i launch the dlc, i tried a second save file and it still crashes, which is disappointing because i wanted to go 100%. But tbh, the bug is not enough for me to give a negative review to it!

Spider-Man Fan or not, the game is absolutely worth your time!

A Quick-Time-Event game with some occasional web swinging, hack/slash combat, and 60 to 80 collectibles around an open world. Not sure how they made the research missions so bad but they made some of the story missions even worse. Plenty of unskippable cutscenes despite some of them being skippable. Plus, they ducked up the default controller config for steam (again), so button prompts are broken in the very first level, and you CANNOT change it outside big picture mode. Why Steam? You are also required to have your controller on before you even contemplate starting the game or it won't recognize it, so just a heads up for literally everyone to ever play the game that you'll have to troubleshoot these. However, whoever made the MJ/Miles missions mandatory instead of putting a "skip mission" button when they remastered it needs to have their walking privileges revoked. Absolutely did not finish the game, nobody in the history of the world has thought "Man, there's way too much Spider-man in my Spider-man game! Wish I could play as someone else!"

The Miles Morales sequel was better IMO, and it sounds like the third entry fixed a lot of these issues too (supposedly).

I started playing this in August 2022 and didn't finish. There were a lot of crashes and lagging on my not-so-bad PC and I eventually moved on. I just picked it up again slightly more than a year later on an updated PC.

Given a year of patches and a modernized PC, it is really not great to have two crashes by the time I got out of Octavious' lab for the first time. The first crash was when I tried to access Accessibility Settings at the first QTE in the game (I prefer to hold during those instead of tap), the second was when leaving the lab for the first time (perpetual loading screen, force quit after 5 minutes). 

I am really disappointed to have this happen. The game has been out for over a year and I have a good PC. I should not have to worry about crashes.


EDIT: After many more hours playing, the crashes are getting worse. At first, they were often when pausing and exiting the window for a while, then when trying to reload Last Checkpoints (for the Challenges unlocked later in the game), and now I can't even load into my save file from the main menu without a crash.

Pro's

- Decent story, at least in the main story dlc was not really my cup of tea; Except for black cat dlc 
-Good combat, but don't play it on to easy. Otherwise you won't even need to use your gadgets, it will become boring very fast otherwise
- Performance was more than decent, but my pc is way overkill for this game. So i can't judge on this one. 

Cons

Very lame puzzles, but golden advice you can turn the puzzles off in the menu. I guess the developers realized that their puzzles where lame 

Mj and miles are freaking annoying, but lucky their missions where very short.

YOu encountered people playing chess, but never got the option to play a game with them. Instead we got tons of annoying lame puzzles in this game. 

The challenges with screwball was also not really my thing

Some people mentioned save issues,

Conclussion more cons than pro's, but overall i still enjoyed this game. I really think its worth the price tag. But if you dind't played the batman games yet, that should still be your first pick. You can pick those games up way cheaper and are for me still the best hero games

Is it the best of the Spidey stories out there? No. But that's not meant to take anything away from the enjoyment of this game. The story is solid, the gameplay and graphics are amazing, the characters are likable and yeah...the swinging is freaking awesome. I'd give it a solid 8 out of 10. I did find anything I had to do as MJ just got annoying after a while and I didn't feel that it did anything to service the story. But that would be my one and only gripe. I can't wait to play Miles Morales next and then maybe I might actually get a chance to play Spider-Man 2.
